X-Men Origins: Wolverine is not that bad. But it's also not good. It's one of the most balanced-out, down-the-middle, apathetic shrugs of a summer tentpole that I've seen in the many years that I've been following the summer blockbuster.
A clever and briskly made ghost story.
It runs long at over two hours but it is expertly directed, shot, edited, and acted.
Some of the philosophical conversations go on a bit too long but it's still an interesting film with some good performances (and some of the most beautiful actresses on the planet).
We've seen too many movies like Harry Brown before and most of them are better.
The Time Traveler's Wife works when it embraces the magic of its concept, not when it remains tethered to the reality of its execution.

Once again, Tarantino refuses to deliver something easily dissected or discussed, something that has made him one of the most polarizing filmmakers of the last two decades. If only there were more like him.
Akin to watching a home movie made by your neighbor's kids if they happened to be the offspring of a millionaire filmmaker.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's a movie about losing your soul that doesn't really have one.
Little did I know that the 3D would merely be another way to disguise the tremendous lack of effort that went into things like writing, acting, or directing.

So easy to get behind thematically and one with fascinating subject matter, but it's a movie that never gets over some of the stereotypes of its subject matter to present a fully-formed, relatable, human drama.
Easily one of the worst movies of the year (if not the decade), there is not one redeeming quality to All About Steve, an offensive film morally, socially, and to the institution of comedy.
Clever, entertaining, and very, very dark, World's Greatest Dad is unlike any comedy that you've seen this year and, for that fact alone, deserves some attention.

Bateman is simply great. He's reason enough alone to see Extract, but perhaps this is the best overall praise I can pay the film -- I can't possibly imagine anyone who liked Office Space NOT liking Extract.
I'm all for embracing the new and supporting filmmakers with unique visions, but there are still basic tenets of filmmaking that need to be achieved.
The script for Whiteout is shockingly boring, centering around a mystery that wouldn't pass a writer's meeting for CSI: Antarctica.
There's an element of relatable humanity missing from the foundation of trying to tell a story that could have taken six hours in 144 minutes, but there's no denying the power of those 144 minutes.
movie_title: Der Baader Meinhof Komplex (The Baader Meinhof Complex) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A very funny slice of CGI whimsy with a perfect voice cast, interesting visual aesthetic, and even a heartwarming message that doesn't feel pounded down your throat like a hot-dog eating contest.
movie_title: Cloudy With a Chance of Meatballs (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Damon gives the most fascinating and fearless performance of his career.
Arriaga's film beats his audience over the head with the pain of its characters but provides no release, no lessons, and no relatable humanity. It's film for masochists only.
A piece of perfect cinematic poetry, a film that doesn't just capture the work, love, and life of a legendary poet but does do with vibrant, relatable, timeless emotion, innocence, and purity.
Like Blade Runner re-imagined by a twelve-year-old.
The Invention of Lying proves that a killer cast and an amazing, unique concept can take you a long way.
Oswalt's performance alone makes Big Fan worth seeing.
From the opening shots to the best post-credits tag in years, Zombieland attempts nothing but pure fun and completely delivers.
There's very little effort to create something honestly creepy or all that funny. I Sell the Dead too often falls short in both categories with jokes that fall flat and scares that don't register.
A revelatory debut, an inventive, daring, original piece of filmmaking that doesn't just hint at a new arrival on the scene as much as blasts one into the film consciousness.
So few characters in Hollywood thrillers ever feel real. The true achievement of Revanche may be that Spielmann's characters sometimes feel too much so.
A surprisingly effective thriller, featuring good-to-great performances and a taut, interesting screenplay with enough twists and turns to keep the audience entertained for its scant running time.
Vidal sells the story of a woman who may just be going insane. She's very, very good, elevating what Proenza misses.
There's a nice twist or two in Hush and it's reasonably well-made but it feels like a TV movie or, worse, an extended TV episode of an anthology series.
Movies as daring as Moon should be applauded before all little films are replaced by safer, hipper models of themselves.
I swear to you that I have never had a film experience that felt longer than the whopping 149 minutes of Revenge of the Fallen, every single one of which I wish I had spent doing something else.
A more vibrant film than Allen's worst but the screenwriting mistakes and general misanthropy hold it back from being anywhere near his best.
Surveillance starts interesting, gets ugly, and ends kind of boring.
Audience members who find themselves on the same wavelength as Mann and his screenwriters will find enough to talk about to keep them raving about Public Enemies for days.
The movie equivalent of a B-side, a film filled with jokes, characters, and set-ups that weren't deemed interesting enough for the first two films. Don't buy the leftovers.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Filmmaking simply doesn't get much more riveting than Kathryn Bigelow's incredible The Hurt Locker, a cinematic experience unlike any other that you will have this year.
A stunning piece of work that feels both familiar and completely unique at the same time.
The only way to look at Couples Retreat as a bookend to Swingers is to note how far these two talented stars have fallen.
Ceylan finds moments of stunning visual composition and his cast truly delivers, so art-house audiences will more than likely be satisfied by Three Monkeys, even if it's not a knockout punch.
Features multiple beheadings and I think at least half the characters actually see their own intestines. It's not for the faint of heart, but it is often very, very clever.

Kids like to see something new when they head to the theater, something they can talk about on the playground. "Remember when THAT happened?" And I really feel that G-Force delivers in that department.

Orphan is one of the weirdest major studio summer movies in a long time. It's the kid at the summer movie school that no one wants to play with because he's more than a little odd. I always liked kids like that.
A very good dissection of friendship, sexuality, ego, domesticity, and our perceptions about who we are and how far we are willing to go to prove that we are not so easily-defined.
Yet another example of an undeniable truth in drama -- without the right screenplay, the best cast in the world can't make a film worth seeing.
An undeniably ambitious piece of work about infidelity, regret, death, fame, friendship, and love, but it simply got away from one of the most talented comedy writer/directors of the last decade.
Barely works due to the sheer force of talent brought to it by the ensemble but it's not even close to the landslide victory that it should have been.
A generally sweet story brought down by baffling screenwriting decisions and manipulative, mawkish, TV-movie-of-the-week direction.
These are FATAL flaws in the screenplay -- not rooting for the romance to work and not rooting for the lead to find redemption. I wanted God to strike Arlen Faber down in the street.
Julie & Julia works best when it focuses not on how we make something of ourselves but the fact that no one does so alone.
What the film does right, I adore. And, like a love-struck romantic wearing rose-colored glasses, I think I'll continue to overlook the flaws of the movie when it comes into my life in the future.
A riveting tale of a small group of people doing very bad (and pretty dumb) things, The Square works from beginning to end and stands as one of the best feature debuts of the year to date.
I'm not ready in the current marketplace of boring junk to yet say that a movie can be TOO clever. Although Micmacs sure tests that theory.

A summer blockbuster that's interesting without ever being riveting; entertaining without ever being thrilling. Summer 2010 has started with a piece of popcorn entertainment that just happens to taste like it was popped in 2008.

None of the relationships that drive this awkward dramedy ring true and only a few supporting performances make the effort worthwhile as they highlight the weaknesses at the core of the manipulative script.

With at least three-too-many endings, paper-thin supporting characters, and predictable twists, The Lincoln Lawyer doesn't deliver as a thriller even if its title character is one of the most interesting of the year to date.
Another unique story that is both moving and also believable at the same time, an increasingly-rare combination. "Win Win" is the first great film of 2011.
Sometimes a bit too episodic and stuffed with history to register emotionally but the three central performances carry the piece overall.
Like the best sci-fi, Source Code is both entertaining and thought-provoking.
At its foundation, it's a movie I like. It's what's built on that foundation that's troubling.
With an A-list cast and incredible production values, Hanna is a speeding train. Hop on and hold on tight.
A tonally inconsistent comedy that nevertheless features one of my absolute favorite performances of the year so far and enough interesting ideas to warrant a look.
After most David Gordon Green movies I couldn't wait to see them again. Unless I'm being tortured, I'll never see Your Highness again.

This fascinating documentary shines a light into an underreported corner of America, the backyards and living rooms that currently house deadly exotic animals that should never have found themselves in captivity at all, much less as pets.
movie_title: The Elephant In The Living Room (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Aspires to be more than an episode of Behind the Music and succeeds largely due to the amazing talent of the band it chronicles, the stunning, one-and-only Fishbone.
movie_title: Everyday Sunshine: The Story of Fishbone (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Wes Craven proves yet again that he has the ability to bounce back and offer a bloody slice of entertainment as well-made as most of the films he has inspired in the decades since his debut.
The characters, the jokes, and even the striking visuals - they all dissipate from the memory like a piece of candy that seems tasty in the moment but ultimately isn't very filling.
I admire it almost purely for its performances and wish the story had the power to match what the actors are bringing to it.
A well-intentioned documentary that is just too unfocused, scattered, and philosophically thin to matter.
A confident piece of genre filmmaking that not only deserves a wider audience but hints at truly great things to come for its talented director.

The calendar may say that Summer is a few months away, but the escapist entertainment that the season is known for starts today with the release of this rocking thrill ride, one of the most purely enjoyable movies in a long time.
This is a daring drama, a true risk for everyone involved that pays off with an emotionally rewarding piece about mental illness, family ties, and turning points.
From the cheesy score to the nonsensical plot to the half-asleep performances, Passion Play is a snooze.
It's so far over-the-top that it makes Machete look believable, but that's why it's effective. Unlike so many movies you will see this season, Hobo With a Shotgun delivers.

Star Kristen Wiig (and she really should be a Star with a capital S after this breakthrough performance) finds the humanity usually missing from not just the chick flick but the modern comedy in general.
Battle Los Angeles is so derivative of superior films that you'll spend half the running time merely making a list of movies that you'd rather be watching.
The result is a film that has marveled people with its labyrinthine plotting but that ultimately feels about as deep as a speed date. You never really get to know it.
The moral and spiritual dilemma at the foundation of Xavier Beauvois's award-winning Of Gods and Men is a fascinating one that drives this complex drama in a way that sears it into memory.
A hit-and-miss affair that falls too often on the wrong side of that comedy corridor.
Like a Big Mac, Unstoppable may not be that good for you, but it will probably leave a smile on your face.
With two strong central performances, a wonderfully genuine style, and some daring filmmaking decisions, Monsters will have a Godzilla-sized following develop over the next few years.
The films of the masterful French director Claire Denis often brilliantly portray the true complexity of life.

Sally Hawkins, Miranda Richardson, Rosamund Pike, Bob Hoskins, and a talented group of mostly newcomers rarely hit a false note and characters one can believe in go a long way in a film such as this one.
This is a music video; an ego piece for two fading stars that is one of the most creatively bankrupt pieces of cinema in years. Actually, most music videos are better.

With creative expression rarely seen in American film and one of the best performances by an actress that you will ever see, Black Swan is a film that resonates for hours and even days after you see it.
It's somewhat appropriate that the movie nearly debuted on DVD stateside since it's worth a rental for Carrey but too frustrating for the cost of theatrical admission.
Anthony Mackie and Kerry Washington nearly rescue the piece but it just doesn't come together into anything memorable enough to recommend.
It's a movie that simply works. Is it great art? Not really. It's not ambitious enough to be called great art. But it is great entertainment.
The King's Speech is a good film that's been inflated by some viewers to great even if it doesn't quite deserve the throne.

A minimalist mood piece and that mood is the melancholy that comes with the realization that you've accomplished very little of real significance and your daily routine is nothing more than varying cycles of self-fulfillment.
It's somewhat disappointing to say that I merely like it. I understand why people will fall head over heels for it but my feet stayed firmly on the ground.
With some of the best performances of the year from Nicole Kidman, Aaron Eckhart, and Dianne Wiest, this is one of the strongest dramas of the awards season.
Gosling and co-stars Kirsten Dunst and Frank Langella don't do anything wrong here but the movie is such a mash-up of tones, fiction, and reality that it never comes together into anything coherent.
A powerful drama, partially made so by a fantastic script, but mostly due to two of the best performances of the year from Ryan Gosling and Michelle Williams. Don't miss it.
Leigh has made another must-see for art house film goers. He simply does every time he gets behind the camera.

With an overdone score, horrendous script, choppy editing, and bizarre tone changes, Kalamity is just weird in that B-movie, straight-to-video way that sometimes distinguishes films into the so-bad-it's-good genre but not quite here.
If you have a masochistic desire to see unlikable morons on a vacation you probably can't afford, check out one of the worst movies in a long time.

It's hard to believe that these are the ten best shorts of the year but it's a case of a good program that is only disappointing if one hopes that the Oscar nominees would be great instead of just good.
movie_title: The Oscar Nominated Short Films: Animation (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to believe that these are the ten best shorts of the year but it's a case of a good program that is only disappointing if one hopes that the Oscar nominees would be great instead of just good.

The elements are there - a (mostly) strong ensemble, an interesting concept, an intriguing location, a promising director - but the film never comes together because the script needed one more rewrite that it just never received.
A nearly-great movie, a rare piece that merges romance and science fiction into something that is at-times mesmerizing.
He stretches the saga of Spitzer a bit too thin with a nearly two-hour running time that his story really can't support but this is still a mostly-fascinating film.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like a knock-off of Chuck Palahniuk produced by people raised only on Sundance films, "Hesher" is a mess.
Allen's most insightful and enjoyable screenplay since the mid-'90s, Midnight in Paris is a lovely summer surprise.
It's a hollow film, concerned more with detail than emotion or character and so it comes off more like a filmmaking exercise than an engaging story, and it never justifies its existence.
There's a reason this clunker is being buried at the end of August and wasn't screened for most critics -- it shouldn't screen for most audiences either.

Running less than two hours but as packed with incredible actors and subplots as an Irwin Allen disaster pic, and yet Soderbergh never lets it get away from him. We always care. We're always interested. We're always terrified.

If you took this script to any sane film producer, they would assume you were pulling a prank. When you told them the shockingly untalented Nick Swardson was attached as the lead, they'd call security.
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An amazing thriller, a modern examination of heroism filtered through the fairy tale culture of the underbelly of the movie machine that is easily one of the most memorable and effective films of not just this year but the last several.
Features characters less three-dimensional than most cartoons doing and saying things that are only done and said in movies. Bad movies. Really bad movies.
It may not be grounded enough to be emotionally effective, but another strong performance from the stellar Mia Wasikowska and a consistency to its vision make Restless worth a look.
He gets to find love, kick some ass, and even kill some bad guys. And all of it is very, very silly.
Very few music documentaries in the history of the form have more successfully conveyed the inner workings and outer artistic expression of a band than Cameron Crowe's brilliant Pearl Jam Twenty.

The tightrope act of a script by Will Reiser is elevated in remarkable ways by one of the best ensembles of the year, led ably by the great Joseph Gordon-Levitt, doing career-best, Oscar nomination-worthy work.
A pale excuse for a chick flick that should look even more ghostly in light of the similarly-themed and far-superior Bridesmaids earlier this year.
What's so unbelievably disappointing about The Human Centipede II (Full Sequence) is not that it's unbelievably disgusting but that it's so unbelievably dumb.
One of the best films of 2011, a stunningly original examination of that which is completely out of our control.
I can't shake this haunting work, one that increasingly grows in esteem the more I swirl it around my brain. It is undeniably one of the more memorable and intriguing works of 2011.
The Dardennes create tension out of human drama and draw believable, excellent performances from their entire cast.
One of those fascinating horror movies that never gets too weird to lose its footing but also stays completely unpredictable.
A fresh take on the potentially-doomed romance with a breakthrough performance from the lovely Felicity Jones and yet another strong turn from Anton Yelchin.
It's a film that becomes almost numbing in its tone but it's incredibly well-made and performed.

Clever horror/comedy hybrid of the kind that Sam Raimi used to make and that so many have tried to produce in recent years but have fallen remarkably flat. There's nothing flat about this clever genre flick. For the right audience, it's pretty great.
An old-fashioned drama about the will of good young men triumphing over the weakness of evil old ones. We've seen it before, but when it's done this well that doesn't seem to matter.
Shuttle could have worked but it is so bogged down with clichés and predictable twists that it comes apart at its illogical seams.
There are Gothic elements that work, but the story simply isn't strong enough to support a remake and lackluster direction fails to iron out the flaws in this potential horror hit.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Thanks to brilliant directorial decisions matched by a cast that was clearly inspired by this unique effort, this will surely be one of the most memorable films of 2011.
As so many films get lost in the Friday shuffle of new releases, it seems easier for a quality, smaller film to miss its audience. Don't lose Warrior. It's one of the best films of 2011.

This is a graphic, dark, violent piece of drama, as it should be given its subject matter, but it's the work of one of our best working actresses that truly makes it worth venturing into the darkness.
It absolutely, undeniably delivers the goods. And those goods are soaked in blood.
If you truly give in to the beauty of this amazing film, you might even find yourself changed by it. How often can you say that at the cinema?
Features a spectacular mix of well-choreographed action, revisionist history, themes of tolerance, and great performances. This will be one of the best movies of this season.
Halfway through Super 8 I stopped thinking about the films that inspired Abrams to make it and started envisioning the works that would be inspired by THIS movie. Yes, it's that good.
Whatever flaws the film may have, it's certainly unlike anything else in theaters right now.
There's little debate that the Chicago-set climax of Michael Bay's third film based on Hasbro's line of toys delivers what it promises. Sadly, the previous 100 minutes are nearly intolerable.
A film that can sometimes feel oddly episodic and that is clearly telling a story that's still being written, but one that could start a number of interesting post-movie conversations.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: We've seen everything here before and in a better film. John Carpenter used to be such a leader, it's hard to watch him follow and so far behind the pace.
With stellar comic timing from the entire ensemble and a dark streak of edgy humor with just enough wit to make it not seem cruel, this is one of the straight-up funniest movies of the year.
A focused, very good documentary instead of the great one that could have been crafted from this bizarre true tale with a bit more scope.
It's hard to imagine fans leaving the final Potter film with deep disappointment in this satisfying conclusion.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The film features two of the least effective lead performances of the year, which keeps the audience from engaging in the story emotionally and just leaves them wondering how this book became a bestseller.
movie_title: Snow Flower And The Secret Fan (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A film that unabashedly believes in the craziness and the stupidity of what we call love. It's also one of the most purely entertaining films of the year.
With so many revisions from a number of writers, it feels like everyone added their own color to the piece until it all faded to gray.
Despite the best efforts by Jenna Fischer playing against type as a smoking, drinking newly-single mother, A Little Help is a mess.
The line for this future cult hit starts here. Get in it before your friends tell you to.
There are moments in The Change-Up that honestly made me feel like a twelve-year-old boy took over his dad's screenwriting project.
What could have been a clichéd oil-and-water buddy movie in a lesser writer's hands feels organic and genuine.
The biggest surprise in a long time simply delivers what it promises and then goes way beyond that to become one of the most memorable summer thrill rides of the last few years.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: With crackerjack pacing and a driven, no-frills script that brings the whole thing to a lean close in under 80 minutes (sans credits), Point Blank is an adrenalin-driven shot to the arthouse scene.
Definitely marks an uptick after the last horrendous installment and it has moments that work but it ultimately fails to add anything new to the unexpected Final Destination anthology.
With so many of the elements missing from the horror genre in the '10s, this is one of the best scary movies Hollywood has produced in a long time.

Samuel Bayer's remake of Wes Craven's A Nightmare on Elm Street may be about repressed memories coming back in horrific ways, but it ironically ends up one of the least memorable films of 2010 to date.

Doesn't have that memorable a story and isn't as visually creative as it should be but you can't find actors much better at this kind of material than Will Ferrell, Tina Fey, Brad Pitt, Jonah Hill, and David Cross.
Stone starts interesting, gets better, and then simply sits there until it ends with a whimper instead of a much-needed bang.
A fascinating, enlightening look at the dark side of show business and the issues that come with being a part of it for decades.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It plays like a film that's not done yet, as if the editor hated watching it repeatedly and simply refused to finish.
Brilliantly tying up the two films that came before in a way that so many sequels fail to do, the geniuses at Pixar have done it again. It's another masterpiece.
One of those films that constantly feels like it could have and should have been better as it threatens to come together but doesn't quite do so.
It may be called Grown Ups, but too much of the new Adam Sandler ensemble comedy feels like it was written by an eight-year-old boy.
I Am Love is a raving piece of filmmaking but its technical beauty is in the service of a story that too often feels clichéd and contrived.
If you're a noir fan interested in seeing a unique modern take on the timeless genre, don't miss this challenging but often fascinating drama.
A heartbreakingly real and hilarious character study about a man trying to put the pieces back together and discovering one of the new ones in his life doesn't quite fit. Don't miss it.
Even viewers caught unaware of just how natural this documentary is could easily find themselves mesmerized by its unique charms.
Finally allows those of us unfamiliar with the books by Stephenie Meyer to understand why the saga of the vampire, the wolf, and the sullen girl in the middle has become an international phenomenon.
The kind of unabashed embarrassment that should send people to their attorneys to see if there's any legal way to get it removed from their pages on IMDB, Wikipedia, and the like.
May be a light lunch compared to the full meal of some other recent French offerings but it still tastes damn good.
movie_title: Let it Rain (Parlez-moi de la pluie) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's certainly possible that yet another summer masterpiece from Pixar has made me cynical about animation from other studios but, to this viewer, Despicable Me doesn't follow through on its clever opening act.
A well-intentioned film that nonetheless falls head first into the kind of surface-level clichés and stereotypes that are usually reserved for basic cable TV movies.

I almost enjoyed the economy of the thrills more than the density of the first movie. And the performances the second time around are more accomplished as Rapace and Nyqvist clearly know their characters inside and out.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: You'd be advised to forget [REC] 2 even exists. Go watch the original if you've never seen it or even check out Quarantine. You'll be much better off.
It's a great piece of filmmaking because of its characters, all of whom feel genuine and three-dimensional in ways that typical screenwriting fails to pull off.

Almost a quarter-century after the B-movie that launched an improbable franchise, we get a reboot that simply spins it wheels, content to deliver exactly what most will expect from it and absolutely nothing more.
Inception is a film about a man who wants to implant an idea in another man's mind. The reason it's a masterpiece is because Christopher Nolan somehow found his way into mine.
A film obsessed with the idea of magic that doesn't bother to stop and create any of its own.
An amazing glimpse into not only what could have been but how easy it is for a filmmaker to go down the rabbit hole into his own project-killing obsessive behavior.

A constant fight of one kick forward, one kick backward when it comes to overall quality but it ends on the front foot and so barely works by virtue of leaving the audience with a smile on their face.
Angelina Jolie is great and the film is undeniably expertly made but it's also shockingly lacking in personality or moments to make it register as more than just an extended chase scene.

It's a film that leaves me very conflicted in that I wish there were more like it in theory and I love star Colin Farrell's recent career decisions, but a film cannot be judged on intentions and Ondine simply doesn't float.
Carnahan, his talented production team, and most of his cast have worked together to create an old-fashioned summer action movie. It's nowhere near an "A," but it easily deserves a passing grade.

Hollywood will try to sell you all summer long on their latest blockbuster being the thrill ride to beat this season. It will be a movie miracle if any of them are as straight-up entertaining as The Good, the Bad, the Weird.
movie_title: The Good, the Bad, the Weird (Joheun-nom, Nabbeun-nom, Isanghan-nom) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Please Give proves that a film can be a spectacularly rewarding experience by just providing time spent with well-written, believable adult characters.
Spoiler alert: babies are similar around the world. That's it. While that may be just barely enough to hold together a TV special, it's not nearly enough for a feature documentary.
Too sentimental for art house crowds and too dirty for multiplex folk, The Good Heart is a movie without an audience about characters that never feel like they really exist.
It's far from a complete disaster but more of an incomplete experience, unless you just looking to see something totally gross.
Rarely has the story of an outlaw of the people been so uninspiring.

I want to live in the alternate universe where Vanessa Redgrave's Claire is the lead of Letters to Juliet and the two vapid dorks who trail her on a journey of lost love can learn a lesson or two but never take the spotlight.
It's an informative, interesting documentary that just barely comes together enough and tells an important enough story to merit a look, but it's not the film that it could have been.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: From the minute that Queen Latifah and Common share a scene together in this relatively light romantic tale, their combined screen charisma blends together in way that makes the generic script that follows much easier to take.
Bronstein's performance and the gentle, unforced directorial work by the Safdies distinguish a film about an all-too-undistinguished father.

Every frame of this film reeks of a project that has been conceived and executed merely to fulfill the bare minimum to get audiences into seats. They know that if they tell a few jokes and bring back the characters you love, that you'll pay to see it. Act
King can't keep a straight face for long enough to make it work, sabotaging his own characters for the sake of a shallow karaoke number. Don't sing along.
Imagine watching someone else play a video game while another guy narrates it.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Like a zombie version of his previous movies %u2013 feeding off what came before and just not quite all there.
The story is nonexistent and the dialogue so self-conscious that the entire proceeding becomes as numbing as someone reading a mediocre book aloud.
movie_title: The City of Your Final Destination (2010)

movie_review_blurb: If it comes anywhere near your town, go see it and thank the movie Gods that it even exists. There's no star rating high enough.
It feels like too many character corners were cut, removing the depth that would make the proceedings believable, and leaving only the cliché.
One of the most surprisingly enjoyable and consistent comedies of the year.
The horror genre needs more films like this one; works made by filmmakers willing to take chances and deliver something to viewers that they would never expect.
This is a film that begins and ends with a fart joke. And those are two of the highlights.
Sequelitis is apparently not purely an American phenomenon.
movie_title: OSS 117: Rio ne répond plus (Lost in Rio) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Solitary Man may be about a man who has found himself on his own, but it features one of the best ensemble performances of the year. Don't miss it.
Retains some of the inherent power of it source and features some strong performances in the process but never finds the narrative cohesion needed to translate it to modern movie audiences.
Successful on its own terms in its refusal to talk down to its pre-teen audience and through the massive future star-power of its talented young stars.

The blend of styles with Rudd's everyman realism, Roach's pedestrian visual sense, and the script's "wacky" humor results in a stew of a comedy in which the divergent ingredients never gel into one coherent movie dish.
The film is proof that even extremely over-the-top films can be monotonous in that their one tone is "ARGH!"
You are unlikely to see a documentary this year more powerful than The Tillman Story.
An elaborate piece of performance art or a documentary about an identity crisis of a man committing professional suicide? Either way, I'm Still Here is grating, boring, and completely without value.
There's nothing minor about the central performances in this film, even if they're in the pursuit of something that just doesn't quite work overall.
A great little character-driven comedy, merely another excellent film from a spectacular director who would be a household name if foreign films got the audience they deserved in this country.

With no characters worth caring about, a heavy reliance on a final-act twist, and absolutely no sense of suspense, "Devil" completely blows the chance to build on what could have been an effective story.
Features a commitment to craft that helps overcome issues of storytelling by providing a visceral, violent experience designed to get you in your gut and bones more than in your heart or head.

A comedy with a mega-talented lead star and wonderful supporting actors all left adrift by a script that vacillates between satire and social commentary but never forgets to remind you that its characters are oh-so-clever.
A great vehicle for Shia LaBeouf, Josh Brolin and Michael Douglas that occasionally disappoints but crackles more often than it fizzles.
A subtle, slow-moving drama of moments and repercussions that works due to the talents of its cast and quality of its source material despite a few notable flaws.
With career-best work from Ryan Reynolds, Buried will find a loyal, devoted audience.
I won't soon forget Kathy, Tommy, and Ruth and that's the film's most essential accomplishment. They haunt you.
With spectacular performances, technical elements that are beyond criticism, and the best directorial work of Fincher's remarkable career, The Social Network is one of the best films of 2010.
Stands firmly on its own two bare feet as not only one of the best horror films of the year but one of the best films, period.
Miscast, poorly-directed, and just-plain boring, Case 39 never clicks into place.

The power of "Waste Land" is two-fold since not only is Muniz using art to shed light into a dark corner of the world but so is Walker with her film. Consistently entertaining and thoroughly fascinating.
Will eventually be remembered as one of Eastwood's best films of this period of his remarkable career.
At its best, 127 Hours is transporting in the way it puts us right in the middle of Aron Ralston's ordeal and perfectly conveys what forced him to make a decision that many of us couldn't conceive.
Owen gives the best performance he's delivered since Children of Men and Liberato gives one of the best teenage performances ever.
When people this talented get together there's an expectation of entertainment that this inert comic book adaptation just doesn't deliver.
Incredibly complicated but never dry, never confusing, and always riveting.
Public Enemy #1 proves the theory that a film must be more than the sum of its parts. These movies both have some great parts but the sum is less than a masterpiece.
This is easily the scariest movie of the year, but like a lot of horror films, it goes a bit past the line that it needed to in order to make its point and loses its effectiveness through overkill.
A piece that feels more like foreign films of the 1960s and 1970s than what viewers would expect from an Oscar winner in 2010. No wonder it's getting buried. It's too good.

The film around its riveting central performance may be a little more flawed than the entire project's international reputation would have you believe but Vincent Cassel alone makes a trip to Mesrine: Killer Instinct worth the time.
It's not often that a behind-the-scenes documentary is more entertaining than the movie itself but Best Worst Movie is not your typical Hollywood tale. There's nothing typical about Troll 2.
There's a decent drama buried in Charlie St. Cloud if the writers and director had the nerve to remove the film of all of its supernatural tricks, all of which feel much more maudlin than genuine.
Lucy Walker's Countdown to Zero is the most terrifying film of the year and one of the most frightening documentaries in a long time.

With so many genre films cluttering themselves with personality-less victims, it's rarer than ever to see a movie that hearkens back to a day when the actors and their characters were as important as the twists, turns, and gore.
Middle Men would be lucky to rise to the median of a list of the films released in 2010. It's actually pretty far below "middle."
For the first time in a long time, I'm not just curious about what this divisive director will do next but excited. It took going back to an old tune for Todd Solondz to find his voice again.
Brancaccio and Zeman don't offer any easy answers, merely throwing all of the many issues of the story of Cropsey into a melting pot of danger, terror, and secrecy.
The flaws don't outweigh the fact that most of The Other Guys is straight-up funny.
Worth seeing for Duvall's performance alone and it heralds the arrival of a very interesting and creative young director in Schneider.
Despite its flaws, an intelligent, beautiful-looking film about the power of one person to radically change the life of another is an unexpected treat in a season of mindless entertainment.
There's nothing wrong with a guilty pleasure. We all have them: Those movies that we know suck that we can't help but watch on cable every time they come on. But they still SUCK.

This is the rare "chick flick" that treats its demographic with respect, never becoming the sentimental or manipulative dreck that so many other filmmakers would have delivered from Elizabeth Gilbert's bestselling memoirs.
Pulcini & Berman's work cuts its own path through the archetypes and delivers a unique comedy in the process.

You won't see anything like this again for a long time. It's an imperfect film that can get downright frustrating but it displays enough flashes of genius to warrant your time and demand your forgiveness of flaws.
The very likable young leads salvage this broad comedy from complete disaster but you know you're in trouble when Bow Wow is the best thing about a movie.
A well-intentioned slice of melodrama but all the good intentions in the world can't hide the film's many, many flaws.
A subtle, quiet, slow film that succeeds in not only burrowing under your skin and into your mind during its running time but has a remarkable ability to stay there for days and weeks afterward.

A ridiculous gore-fest that falls completely flat in terms of character, dialogue, and logic but pops off the screen in the areas in which it really counts for a movie about prehistoric man-eating fish.
A few notable set-pieces and the incredible performance by Cassel save Killer Instinct from the traps it sets for itself.

We all remember the days when the smallest act of kindness or meanness changed everything and, thanks to two very strong central performances, Flipped captures the essence of those times in a gentle, sentimental romance.
An above-average heist thriller that's undone by poor screenwriting and worse post-production.
Daniel Stamm's The Last Exorcism is one of the most interesting and accomplished horror debuts of the last few years.
A dark thriller that doesn't completely come together but Thomsen's excellent performance keeps it from falling apart and fans of left-of-center suspense films should take a look.
When you start thinking that the Taco Bell pitchwoman is perhaps too good for the material, you know the script has some serious problems.
A film that's a total mess, but in kind of a beautiful way.
Some might call it a mess, but, unlike the average horror sequel that's completely devoid of new ideas, this is a mess that you just can't stop watching.
It's cool, man. But don't be surprised if you wish it was funnier, dude.
For many people, including me, the visual virtuosity behind Angel-A will be more than enough to get them over the storytelling bumps and the character inconsistencies.
Soderbergh regains the balance he found in the first film and, in some ways, even improves on it.
A perfect example of a filmmaking rule that seems to be true no matter what the country of origin - sequels are always bigger, louder, and crazier than the first one.
It's like a lazy summer day - too light and inconsequential to really get excited about, but you have to be pretty cranky to complain too loudly.
An intellectual, character-driven horror film, one that gets under your skin not through your stomach, but through your nightmares.
Starts off great, ends up merely not baaaaaaaa-d.
A welcome escape and eventual cult hit for comedy fans this summer.
A lot like the fireworks of the holiday that it's set on - nothing more than loud, mindless, and, only when the biggest explosions go off, the kind of fun you were hoping for.
The best animated movie in well over a year, and one of the most magical, enjoyable movie experiences you'll have at the theater this summer or any time else this year.
Every time Transformers threatens to collapse under the weight of its ridiculous plot and boring characters, Bay and his team pull a visual trick that will blow many summer movie fan's minds.
While Ratliff deserves credit for trying to use real demons - postpartum depression, child abuse - as elements of horror, Joshua fails to thrill because it never feels remotely realistic.
Easily the darkest of a series that has grown increasingly dim, Phoenix rises to the occasion, even if it doesn't fly quite as high as the previous two installments.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You won't care if they walk down the aisle or off a short pier.
Only about twelve people you know are likely to ever see the film. Eleven will hate it. Avoid hanging out with the twelfth.
Watching Zahn and Bale at the top of their game will get audiences over any storytelling speed bumps in Rescue Dawn.
While the final result isn't entirely cloud-free, there's still enough silver lining to make this trip to the sun worthwhile.
As your parents told you when you brought home the wrong girl or guy, you deserve better.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more likeable films of the year, an unexpected surprise on every level that will likely keep toes tapping through its theatrical run and far beyond.
The first ten minutes are funnier than 95% of the comedies released this year. Everything else is gravy.
Mr. Brooks had the potential to be a ridiculous thrill ride, but that requires a director who knows how to shoot a scene with more style than a Law & Order episode.
A good writer starts with characters and plot and allows the themes to come naturally from the story. Sean Ellis' script for Cashback is all theme, and it's not that interesting a one to begin with.
Anyone who ever thought that maybe they could write a movie will, at least once, think to themselves, "I could have done so much better with this idea."
Ashley Judd gives the kind of fearless, raw performance that you only see a few times a year.
Cassavetes, first and foremost, made Alpha Dog a great ensemble piece, a decision that really distinguishes the film from its lesser teenage crime counterparts.
Even if the film is essentially a one-man show, a one-man show starring John Malkovich is bound to be really damn good.
Definitely pushes the envelope of crotch jokes and slapstick humor, but there are enough completely original bits that work to recommend it.
Regardless of what you think of the story and characters in Robinsons, the film should be seen just for the technological advancement it represents.
An original, intriguing thriller with two excellent performances by a pair of the best young actors working today
It's hard to believe that when God does reap his vengeance that it will be this boring.
Is the return of these two undeniably talented filmmakers to the house of grind fun? To put it in the simple kind of terms you'd be likely to hear in a grindhouse movie - hell yeah.
Disturbia stands above most of its genre neighbors by realizing that it's the minutes that come before the last-minute twist that really count.
The end of the road almost makes this a path worth taking, but most audience members will probably be too bored by the time the movie finally gets there to really care.
Redline is the kind of movie where they spent so much on the fast cars they forgot to save any for acting lessons or screenplay rewrites.
The only reason this movie might not win any Razzies next year is because no one will remember it even came out.
At the end of the year, Hot Fuzz may be both your favorite comedy and your favorite action movie of 2007, and that's no joke.
There will be few better examples all year of how much a script can be elevated by the actors involved.
You'll start to wonder if anyone grasped the irony of making a movie about snuff films that actually kind of feels like one itself.
The most notable thing about The Condemned is how it manages to be both ridiculously dull and incredibly offensive at the same time.
Next forces you to not just suspend your disbelief but take it out back and shoot it in the head.
There's nothing awful about The Invisible, there's just nothing memorable either.
The first major summer movie of 2007 is going to leave fans very happy and probably justify repeat viewings long into the warmer months.
28 Weeks Later eventually hits the ground like a "Rage Virus" victim getting a drop of infected blood in his eye - quickly, loudly, and without a thought in the world.
If you enjoyed the first two Shreks and don't mind paying again for something you've kind of seen before, you won't be disappointed.
At World's End is so insanely plot-heavy that it requires scene after scene of exposition, and the whole thing sinks simply under the weight of the story.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: One of the raunchiest, dirtiest, most hilarious movies in recent memory and, hands down, the best American comedy of the year so far.
In a year when a lot of big-screen animation felt like it came rolling off the video game assembly line, a little originality goes a long way.
movie_title: Arthur and the Invisibles (Arthur and the Minimoys) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Much like the career of its star, I Know Who Killed Me opens promisingly, starts to stumble in the middle and has gotten so laughably ridiculous by the final act that you can't take it seriously at all.
Samberg and Schaffer just didn't provide enough gas for this groaning moped of a movie, and it fizzles out before Rod even gets to the ramp.
Penn hits too many of his thematic nails square on the head, never trusting that his audience is intelligent enough to get his message without all of that bold-facing and underlining.
Every moment in The Kingdom is shrouded with the threat of violence, until it finally explodes in a last reel that's one of the most heart-pounding action scenes in years.
The Darjeeling Limited is like an artist attempting to play back the exact same song, note for note. It's almost always better the first time.
A dense trip into the gray areas of the legal world that film fans will go back to again and again like the classics that inspired it. Don't miss it.
The genre is bound to have its superstars and average contenders. Unfortunately, despite its production value, The Seeker is one of the latter
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: With the brilliance of what Stiller has done before to compare it to, the title seems fitting on a couple of levels.
One of the more entertaining films of the season, a tight, efficient thriller with two actors, a director, and a writer firing on all creative cylinders
You can almost see them give up about halfway through, beaten down by a script that gives them almost no character development or interesting action.
If you're a fan of strong acting performances, you really should grab the Kleenex and take the trip
It turns out that we've had our Afflecks mixed up for years.
Your enjoyment of Hollywood's latest vampire flick, 30 Days of Night, is largely going to depend on how forgiving you are towards the flaws of the Underworld movies.
Things We Lost in the Fire could have easily turned into chest-thumping and wailing for two hours, but it's a lot more than that.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Saw IV almost makes you believe there are hundreds of rooms out there at this very minute with puppets, tricycles, and audio tapes just waiting for the next game.
"Dan in Only-in-the-Movies Life" would have been an awkwardly long title, but it would have been a lot more appropriate.
Despite good work by the two leads to put it back together again, Broken lives up to its title.

Kohn is a talented filmmaker and he's tackled a subject not seen before in documentary film, but you almost feel bludgeoned by the depressing state of Brazil instead of introduced to the problems there.
Riley delivers a tremendous performance, not so much a mimic as a wholesale recreation of another human being.
You'll feel like you're at an amazing eulogy, where friends and family don't mourn the loss of their loved one but tell stories about his life.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You'll admire American Gangster, but it never gets under your skin or sticks in your memory. It's a good film that feels like it could have been great.
One of the better animated films of the year, an enjoyable and consistently clever ride courtesy of the very original comic viewpoint of the man who made arguably the best sitcom of all time.
Lake of Fire doesn't tell you what to decide, it just gives you as much information as possible to make the choice yourself.
Stunning visuals, award-worthy performances, and a script that takes incredibly rewarding risks, Jesse James is a masterpiece and one of the best films of the year.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Greengrass gives audiences a contact high from his visual flair alone and proves that he's one of the more interesting and entertaining directors working today, no matter what the genre.
Hopefully, The Hunting Party will find the success it needs to keep Shepard making off-center movies because Hollywood doesn't always reward hard-to-categorize films like this one.
If there's a lesson to be learned from the third film, it's that these flicks need to be all pay-off.
You need to give your audience a reason to care, not just assume they will because your subject was important to the history of music.
I wish that the batting average in The Ten was a little higher, but I'm happy that Wain and Marino got up to the plate and knocked a few out of the park.
There's a bizarre lack of anything to care about beyond the dynamic duo at the center of the film. Chan and Tucker can only carry an audience so far.
The kind of genre-defying project that even an old hat like Peter Jackson would struggle with tone-wise and, despite his valiant effort, Vaughn can't quite seem to get the mix right.
Like attending a reunion or opening a yearbook, I know I'll be looking back fondly on Superbad for years to come, and laugh my ass off every time.
There are moments in Them that are as powerful as anything in the genre in the last few years.
Gordon finds a way to take these relatively normal guys and their simple quest to be the best at something and turns it into a conflict for the ages.
movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A disappointment, failing to capitalize on the charisma of its two leads or even give them anything that interesting to do.
The writers and director bury their own story and never give their audience a reason to care about their journalist's fight for redemption.

You know the feeling you get from the Apatow comedies that the people who made them are really trying to do their best? Balls of Fury has the opposite feeling, as if everything was just "good enough".
Kevin Bacon gives another stellar performance and there are some powerfully good action scenes but the structure of this Sentence doesn't feel like it was ever well-defined.
It's style over substance to be sure, but damn if it isn't a really cool style.

Fully dedicated to finding newer and more creative ways to annihilate countless bad guys, Michael Davis' ultimate guy movie isn't just testosterone-heavy, it's doused with it, sprayed with diesel, and set ablaze.
Even with its flaws, it's a dusty horse ride that's well worth taking and more proof that the western never dies.
Marks the arrival of a very interesting new talent on the scene, one that feels inspired by the grindhouse horror genre and tired of the self-seriousness of the torture trend.
Despite the flaws in the structure and story of Deep Water, Osmond and Rothwell display great skill at keeping their audience informed.
The movie that Ed Wood would have made in the era of CGI, complete with awkward editing, wooden acting, and a story that becomes impossible to care about at all.
Love him or hate him, no one makes movies quite like David Cronenberg, a man who can take an otherwise cut-rate Russian mob thriller and turn it into something absolutely fascinating.
Even though it was stuck in development for a while, it deserved another lap around the screenwriting gym.
An example of how not to let your "grand idea" get the better of you and make you forget about the basics of moviemaking, like character, plot, and, because this one's a musical, people who can sing.
It can never seem to decide if it's escapist action or social commentary and, as a result, it never commits to either.
What if you took one of the underwhelming Matthew McConaughey romantic comedies like Failure to Launch and added T&A, gross-out humor, and the gorgeous Jessica Alba?
You may see films you like better in 2007, but you're unlikely to see one more memorable.
Instead of showing us the differences between the three men, Eastwood chooses to illustrate how much they were alike and, more importantly, how much they resemble you and me.
What allows We Are Marshall to stand above many of the other 2006 sports movies is both the undeniable power of the story itself and the strong ensemble McG gathered to tell it.
One of the better models in a long line of recent horror remakes.
Primeval is bad, but it's never boring, and you can't say that about many of its peers.
The kind of comedy that you'll forget mere moments after seeing.
If you're old enough to read this sentence, you should probably go see something else.
Trying to make a sports movie for the entire family is understandable, but it makes a complicated story like Glory Road feel more like Disney than reality.
Despite its occasionally unfinished feel, Hoodwinked will probably keep everyone (adults and kids) entertained for its very brief running time.
Annapolis throws the same punches as many of its inspirational fellow cadets and almost, but not quite, wins the fight.
A solid ensemble almost saves Firewall, but, in the end, it goes up in campy flames.
Running Scared exists in that world of movies where there are no good guys - just bad guys, worse guys and worst guys.
There's a fine line between old-fashioned and cliched.
Like Craven's original, Aja's version gets the job done - it makes your stomach turn, puts you on edge, and gives you a horror-movie ride.
It's viciously, vibrantly, vigorously, very, very good.
One of those movies that thinks loud sounds and shaky cameras account for scares, and reminding of us of truly scary gaming experiences only amplifies its weaknesses.
Slither is over-the-top, gross, funny, bizarre and totally weird. In other words, it might be just what you're looking for this weekend.
McGuigan has such a stylish eye that, even if you never quite care what's happening, you'll always be visually entertained.
The fast-food of the genre - it "gets the job done" and fills you up, but the hunger for more will undoubtedly return sooner rather than later.
Silent Hill starts out at point A and then goes so quickly, loudly and visually over-the-top that it flies completely off the rails into its own glorious weirdness.
Takes the most documented ghost story in history and doesn't create one truly scary moment.
Making fun of art students is like shooting Darwin fish in a barrel.
It swims but it's one of those sloppy dog paddles your kid brother does more than an Olympic freestyle.
Any movie that can cling to your memory with as much brutal power as this fantastic film is unquestionably a proposition worth taking.
It won't mark the return of the wild west, but it will make fans of the days when quick-drawing was a marketable skill and horses were a man's best friend very, very happy.
A clever and fun escape from the summer blahs.
The biggest and most unfortunate problem with Smokin' Aces is the complete lack of anyone to root for or even against.
Loud, weird, and something you don't want to spend too much time with.
Even with a very-good lead performance, isn't memorable enough to recommend.
The real message to be learned from The Messengers is that audiences need something new to scare them, not the same old ghosts.
So little happens in Blood and Chocolate that it almost serves as a cautionary tale about traveling to Romania - even if you're a werewolf, you're going to be sullen and boring.
The most accurate title might have been "Hannibal Falling" because that's what this film does to the legacy of Hannibal Lecter.
If you're going to make a movie that basically centers around misogyny, racism, and making fun of fat people, why not go all the way and make it an adult R-rated comedy?
Even after watching her rise and fall for 90 minutes, we still don't know her at all.

The Dead Girl is an ambitious, unusual drama, and it's the kind of script that actors kill for, giving them rich, three-dimensional parts that they only have to play for a small amount of time, allowing for full emotional impact.
Screamers isn't didactic; it doesn't tell you how to respond. It just wants you to know and to ask questions.
A well-paced, intelligent thriller that's easily the most pleasant surprise of the year so far.
A family film that recognizes that there are some interesting, intelligent fifth graders out there who aren't obsessed with fart jokes or potty humor.
The Astronaut Farmer just drifts off into space.
It's no longer thrilling or even campy. It's just embarrassing.
Heralds the arrival of a new talent that every horror fan should keep their eyes on, if they're not covering them with their hands.
You have to throw all reason and logic out the window and just feel the groove this movie's laying down.
Technically, Zodiac is as flawless a film as you may see all year.
Filled from first frame to last with images that are meant to burn themselves into your memory and force you to tell your friends about what you just saw.
One of those rare movies that actually transcends all genres and just becomes a great movie, period.
Time traveling to the future isn't the same thing as a "Premonition." But maybe calling it "Nonsense" would have been just a little too honest.
Fans coming from the Saw franchise are going to be bored to death by Dead Silence.
Shooter doesn't try to be anything but a simple piece of pure action escapism and, on that level, it definitely hits the target.
A film that looks like a too-long episode of a Saturday morning cartoon with a health CGI budget.
Being gross and gory is one thing, but the problem with The Hills Have Eyes II is that those elements are literally all it has going for it.
A fantasy for adults that will make you feel both the intense wonder and fear of childhood more than any film in years.
What most will take from Lady Vengeance is a director in love with film and the ability to express that passion through the language of his medium.
Dead Man's Chest is simply something we've been missing most of this entire summer - a film that's truly alive.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The kind of film that will echo deep in your soul.
The genius of Borat is all in Sacha Baron Cohen's daring, edgy, unrestrained performance.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A witty combination of jokes for both adults and kids.
The style doesn't just overwhelm the substance, it makes it irrelevant.
It's an amazing performance, one of the best of the year, with Bale truly making you believe in this over-the-top character.
The Return is a slow burn that's often way too slow, feeling stretched to meet a running time that's still under 90 minutes.
Stranger Than Fiction never rises above its eye-catching premise, ending up as nothing more than a great idea with absolutely nowhere to go.
It's the performances and Linklater's devotion to them and not just the nation that make this a meal worth eating.
It's almost impossible to hate. It's not impossible to get a little bored, but that's another tune.
It's a hard movie to hate, just one that's far too easy to forget.
It's a film that's more likely to leave you confused and angry than frightened or inspired that something positive is happening in the horror genre.
It's escapism - the world would be a lot safer if good and evil were so clearly defined - and it's something that Mel Gibson proves (once again) that he does very, very well in Apocalypto.
It's a film about exploitation that sometimes feels like it IS exploitation and is only going to leave you frustrated.
You may not be expecting this from a musical, but Dreamgirls is one of the most fast-paced, frenetically-edited, roller-coaster rides of a movie that you'll see all year.
It's Soderbergh's commitment and creativity that lift The Good German above many of its peers, no matter the era.
In an effort to make a crowd-pleasing film, the horrors that Gardner must have experienced on the streets feel glossed over by the Hollywood machine.
Like its odds-defying hero, Rocky Balboa is the biggest surprise of the holiday season.
Children of Men feels more relevant than almost every film set in the present day and is better than almost every other film made this year.
The film may not hold up to Hero or Flying Daggers, but it contains enough of those film's stunning visual tricks to make it well worth checking out this holiday season.
In a mystery worthy of the CIA, The Good Shepherd ends up being both too long and too short.
With this cast, there should be more laughs, and that blame falls partially on the script, but equally on how awfully Levy paces the film.
One of the most sadistic, brutal, grisly films of the current splatter-porn genre.
May be the most reverent superhero film ever made.
An example of old-fashioned storytelling, the kind of magical movie that could have been made fifty years ago and, consequently, will still be watched fifty years from now.
A quest to find the humanity behind the imagery of Iwo Jima that never gets beneath the skin to the real men who became heroes with a single camera shot.
Linklater never pretends that he has all the answers, but he asks the questions in such an interesting, elegant fashion that you'll be glad you came along for the ride.
It's a fairy tale that never flies the way it should.
Isn't clever or inventive enough to make up for its repetitive and lackluster storytelling.
It doesn't exploit its characters for comedy or life lessons; it simply embraces the family members and lets them be themselves.
The unanswered questions in the original added to the mood, but by trying to answer even just a few of them, this Pulse just gets more confusing and less scary.
Despite its two strong lead performances and terrific visual verve, The Illusionist ends up as a great example of an overly ambitious movie that's not quite sure what it wants to be.
Sure, Crank is totally ridiculous, unbelievable, exhausting, and pretty much just plain stupid, but that's what makes it fun.
In the final act of The Wicker Man, when Nicolas Cage has donned a bear suit, you have to wonder just what it is you're watching.
May not have all the answers about the death of one of the icons behind the big red 'S,' but by gathering one of the better ensembles of the year, it makes the legend interesting again.
It's tremendously refreshing to see a film that relies solely on the choreography of its athletic star to make the action work.
You have to wonder just how vibrant the film would have been during the Reagan or Clinton administration, when De Palma was in his prime.
The surprisingly effective Gridiron Gang will find its way into that harshly defended emotional endzone, even if they might not necessarily admit it to their friends.
Flyboys doesn't just use cliches - it wallows in them, feeling more like a film based on old war movies than actual history.
The audience just has to work a little too hard to see through the bad editing to the Haven that lies beneath, no matter how interesting and promising that movie may be.
It's almost like getting the band back together, which is great for Jackass fans if they don't mind that the super-group is pretty much set on playing the exact same tune.
Will definitely rescue some moviegoers from the post-summer doldrums, but someone should have told Davis that there's going to be casualities if he leaves audiences in the water that long.
You might want to sign up for study hall instead.
A creative, original work by a filmmaker with a fantastic visual flair who refuses to stick to any typical cinematic patterns, even if it's sometimes to a fault.
Scorsese takes William Monahan's brilliant adaptation and completely makes it his own, resulting in not only one of the best movies of the year but also one of the best of his amazing career.
Audiences will start playing the 'Who's Next' game as people run, scream and die, and the whole thing loses the power that this horrific creation once had over cinema.
movie_title: The Texas Chainsaw Massacre: The Beginning (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Repetition is the death of horror.
You almost have to laugh and go along on the wave of ridiculousness.
Everyone involved will move on to bigger and better things and leave this series of unfortunate events behind on the tracks, waiting for a midnight train to put it out of its considerable misery.
Redford may be well intentioned, but Lions For Lambs comes across as a toothless primer for water-cooler conversation rather than a potent, political piece of filmmaking.
The fact that the story De Palma has chosen is only partially true makes his more extreme decisions feel that much more sadistic.
Kids will need some pretty serious beer goggles to get over the flaws of Sex Drive.
The producers of movies based on video games must think their audience is nothing but easy-to-entertain morons. It's the only explanation for a movie this dark, dull, and dumb.
A frustrating film which will have a life in theaters and for years to come thanks to one central, stunning performance, but is ultimately a wasted opportunity.
We've seen this movie about corrupt cops and the families they take down a thousand times before, but rarely has it been so bafflingly inept in its execution.
A character study in the classic sense of the phrase, featuring a lead who will stick with you for days and weeks to come. It's easily one of the best movies of the year.
When Kuenne picked up his camera and set out to make a love letter to a tragically lost friend, he had no idea what he would find. With Dear Zachary, he found the best documentary of the year.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: May not be perfect, but it does show a filmmaker reinvigorated by his own writing and the potential of the raunchy comedy to be more than just a niche audience product.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Ritchie the director may have returned to form, but Ritchie the writer is still an amorphous mess.
Like most anthologies, has its highs and lows, but is still original and inventive enough to recommend to horror fans looking for something different - a movie that's actually trying to be scary.
movie_title: Peur(s) du Noir (Fear(s) of the Dark) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film that has, for lack of a less overused critical phrase, haunted me since I saw it. There's a deep sadness in Lawrence, Marlee, and James' eyes that is very hard to shake.
Whatever flaws there may be in the script or direction of I've Loved You So Long, it's a must-see for the two performances at its center.
Will undoubtedly pull many a heartstring and make many an audience member shed a tear, but, with a premise and execution this hollow and manipulative, I beg you, don't fall for it.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: All shtick and repetition, something the little ones may find entertaining, but something that will drive parents 2 boredom, 2 another theater, or 2 ask for their money back.
There are enough laughs in Role Models to recommend it if you're desperate, but the first half-hour hints at a great comedy to come and it's just okay instead.
The cast of Synecdoche, New York is so pitch-perfect and the concept so original that it could be the best choice for people looking to exercise their brain's this holiday season.
Drama, comedy, musical, thriller, love story, and more in one transcending, riveting story. It is life on celluloid and, easily, one of the best movies of the year.
Quantum of Solace is the rocking-but-unsatisfying-on-its-own encore to Casino Royale's full set-list and, now, the lights are up and the show is over. I can't wait to hear the next tune.
Even drastically altered as it has been in Ashes of Time Redux, the strengths and weaknesses of the film are the same.
A beautiful, heartbreaking horror film that transcends its genre to become one of the most memorable and powerful movies of the year.
A good film with great performances that's only held back a bit by its extreme length and the pacing and pretentiousness that goes with it.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Cute, clever, and enjoyable.
A return to form for Jonathan Demme, acting tour-de-force for Hathaway, and simply one of the best films of the year.
It's not the ingredients that make a cinematic adventure a "classic epic" - Australia has all of the ingredients - it's how you cook them and this one is overdone.
City of Ember simply doesn't work as entertainment, ending up a cluttered mess and another example for writers to use when they pull the "Sophomore Slump" feature out for publication again.
Maher's wandering eye keeps Religulous - a very good movie - from being the great movie it could have been.
Pineapple Express is one of the best comedies of the year, an original and creative mix of very dark humor, feel-good "best friends comedy," and stoner movie.
[Petit is] such an impassioned and energetic interview subject that it's remarkable that someone didn't make Man on Wire earlier.
Very few directors have been willing to take on a satire as dark and daring as Tropic Thunder. For those of us who were losing hope in Mr. Stiller, it's about time.
A franchise that once inspired the imagination of billions has fallen so far that it can't keep your attention for 98 minutes.
With its consistently clever and always unpredictable screenplay, fascinating setting, and stellar lead performance, Transsiberian is riveting from beginning to end.
One of the most enjoyable and best films of the year.
Hope and faith, by their very nature, are issues that need to be handled with question marks. And yet, Henry Poole Is Here features nothing but ham-fisted periods.
The timing is a bit off with this routine, even if there are a few solos that totally kick ass.
If you're considering seeing Death Race this weekend, send me ten bucks and I'll personally come to your house and punch you in the face instead. It will be more dramatically rewarding.
Elegy excels when it focuses solely on Kingsley and Cruz, two actors who inhabit these roles so completely that they're more interesting than the plot twists that surround them.
Bangkok Dangerous is so deadly dull that it's really not even worth writing or reading about, much less taking the time to see.
This isn't the Coens playing it safe following their Oscar win. Rather, Burn After Reading is a movie about idiots made by geniuses.
A great trio of actors and a talented writer/director inject Lakeview Terrace with enough unexpected left turns to barely keep it worth recommending.
I'm sure a lot of bad fiction has been written about veterans and current soldiers in the Iraq War. It's just not that often that it gets shot and projected on to a big screen.
Like a quickie in a bathroom or a Heimlich to the gut, Choke gets in, gets out, and gets the job done.
The Duchess is this season's "painted cinema." All the colors are there and it's never hard to look at, but it's ultimately as two-dimensional as a trip to the art gallery.
Lee jumps back and forth between melodramatic speeches and unnecessary monologues so much that he loses all the emotional connection that he could possibly find with his audience.

Unwilling to do anything in moderation, the four people it took to write one of the worst screenplays of the year almost seem to be playing a game where they have to top each other with each stupid twist.
There's a little magic there in Cera and Dennings' excellent performances, continuing their upward trajectories in a romantic comedy that can barely keep up with them.

It's as slow and lifeless a crowd pleaser as you'll see all year, a David-and-Goliath story that would have been a much stronger film if it realized that David has to be a little nuts to take on Goliath.
Appaloosa is a familiar story told well enough that it's worth seeing, but won't truly linger for any but the most diehard Western fanatic.
Body of Lies is an expertly made, well-acted movie, and that makes it worth seeing, but it's not what it could have been.
Baghead is an original, confident piece of filmmaking that isn't easily categorized or even summarized.
Seen the first two Transporter movies? Close your eyes and you can picture the third one. There, I just saved you $10.
You haven't seen a film this well written, directed, or acted in a very long time. Milk is a masterpiece.

With some good performances and conscious avoidance of a lot of the trappings of the genre, audiences are likely to fall for this romantic comedy, even if they don't feel good about it in the morning.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Easily the best movie of the young year so far and the first worthy contender for Best Animated Film of 2009.
After years of expectation, Star Wars, Episode I - The Phantom Menace didn't work for most fans of the franchise. Ironically, it feels like people may say the same thing about Fanboys.
There is some deeply moving material in The Class and those who enjoy realistic interplay between characters who blur the line between fiction and reality won't want to miss it.
If you can get out and see them, you should. Some of them are truly spectacular.
Another slasher flick that will ultimately be as influential or memorable as the mediocre sequels that followed one of the most influential horror movies of all time.
One of the most surprisingly inert films so far this year, an awfully written conspiracy flick that never gets out of neutral.
A riveting, fly-on-the-wall documentary using only silent home movies and audio recordings of a family in steep, depressing decline.
The final act, where secrets become revealed and the plot twists in on itself once more is ingeniously clever.
movie_title: Kærlighed på Film (Just Another Love Story) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Such an ambitious and fascinating effort thematically that it's impossible to ignore.
A wonderful character-driven drama about a man caught between what he has and what he wants.
A surprisingly genuine and sweet film.
A clever dissection of romance and friendship that feels nearly like a French Woody Allen film.
movie_title: Un Baiser s'il vous plaît (Shall We Kiss?) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Except for a few strong performances (balanced out by a few awful ones) and the strength of the ideas at the core of Watchmen, the film is a complete disaster, one of the biggest disappointments of the last several years.
It's a film about a supposedly real-world set-up that never feels true, even though the people who made it clearly set out to treat their subject matter and the audience with respect.
All three of the principal players are excellent and the film has a breezy, sexy tone that's harder to pull off than it looks.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Worth seeing for anyone who calls themselves a fan of any of its directors or weird anthology films in general.
