A freakier follow-up featuring creepy kids, villains who'll keep you up at night and camerawork that puts moviegoers in a state of impending dread.
No need to have ever played a video game to enjoy Warcraft, though a healthy affection for swashbuckling action and throwback fantasy probably helps.
Jojo Moyes adapted her own best-selling book, which helps give Me Before You a singular inviting vibe instead of feeling like The Fault in Our Stars 2.
[An] exceedingly absurd Spinal Tap-ping takedown of modern pop music, social media and celebrity crash-and-burns.
Unless a Red Queen road trip is on tap next, it might be time to retire the Looking Glasses for a while.
With Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising, the raunchy college comedy is graduating to smart feminist commentary.
The Revenant is a throwback look at a wild time in American history, and the team-up of Iñárritu and DiCaprio gives this era a deserving epic.
Foster has crafted a piece that, in places, proves to actually be funnier than might be expected, and she gets the most out of her fellow A-listers ...
The latest in the X-Men movie franchise is just X-meh.
Unless your mom has an extremely low bar for movie satisfaction, it's best to do her a favor and skip a date to Mother's Day.
There's a Miracle Mop at the heart of Joy, though the movie is such a mess that even it would have a hard time cleaning up.
Lee knows when it's time to preach and when it's time to entertain.
Although the humor doesn't always go down smoothly, watching two masters work is worth the hangover.
A satisfying look at young unrequited love, bromances, independence and letting go.
Call him "Joltin' Jake" Gyllenhaal, because the actor adds needed presence and punch to the melodrama of Southpaw.
With films such as Funny People and This Is 40, Apatow has toyed with finding the right blend of the serious and the hilarious and finally hits it here.
When it's on its game, Ant-Man does some of the best stuff ever in a Marvel movie.
Even with some familiar faces, The Stanford Prison Experiment feels like an honest-to-goodness documentary - a high compliment for a movie based on an infamous college project.
Brian Lynch's screenplay features a series of amusing sight gags and physical comedy that mostly hits; watching the Minions play polo while riding Corgis is an exercise in cuteness.
Terminator used to be a sci-fi franchise defined by its cool time-travel concept and even better special effects. Unfortunately, it's "Hasta la vista, baby," to those good old days.
MacFarlane and co-writers Alec Sulkin and Wellesley Wild have a gift for referential riffs, but the plot is the thinnest of narratives just to connect all the comedy bits.

Dope digs into racial culture in a real way with Malcolm struggling with the fact that he doesn't fit being a geek or a menace to society, and it's a hoot to root him on as he finds his place somewhere in between.
It's good to get your emotions in check before watching the exquisite Inside Out. You're bound to feel the whole bunch watching a child's mind come alive in the most imaginative ways.
Even though in voiceover Greg tells the audience "this isn't a touching romantic story," that doesn't mean director Alfonso Gomez-Rejon can't have a little fun with expectation.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The action bonanza gets a little lost in its own spycraft, but offers action scenes both fast and furious and a fabulous couple of additions to the world of the IMF (short for Impossible Mission Force, obviously).
World is a monster step up from the two disappointing previous sequels, but is sorely missing the heart and inherent wonder of the classic first film.
The cringeworthy dialogue and unmoving earnestness are the biggest disasters in this mostly forgettable action flick
A spectacular ride for most of it, and while you're a little let down at the end, you kind of want to jump back on and do it all over again.
Kikuchi brought humanity to the robots-vs.-monsters action of Pacific Rim in a small supporting role, and she ups that much more with the meek title character of Kumiko ...
It Follows is yet another example of how smart the indie horror game is these days.
This film is just bad Business for everyone involved.
A whirlwind of horrible British accents, too much gagging and not enough good gags, and weak dialogue that, while not exactly terrible, is terribly boring.
It exists somewhere between serious character study and satirical fish-out-of-water story, never figuring out which it wants to be.

Sattler digs into both sides of those cell doors, exploring the combative side of soldiers having to "babysit" detainees while those inside the prison walls are driven mad by their lack of sleep and unfortunate conditions.
At times Dracula Untold flirts with dullness so much that it might as well just stick a stake in the heart of Bram Stoker's legacy.
Left Behind seriously could have used some divine intervention.
A delectable treat that balances themes of identity and class warfare with Monty Python-style political skewering, quirky humor and dairy jokes.
A prequel story that puts the spotlight squarely on its leading lady and aims to be more heartfelt than horrifying.
An unfortunate movie that does an embarrassing disservice to the decades-old property and is a frightful waste of all the talent involved.
The Cold War returns full force on the big screen, though by the end of The Man from U.N.C.L.E., you might want to put it back in the fridge.
It exists to entertain in its own oddball universe, munchies optional.
[Star Wars: The Force Awakens] returns the iconic sci-fi franchise to a glorious place that hasn't been seen since Ewoks danced off into victory in Return of the Jedi 32 years ago.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Howard creates an immersive, gorgeously shot experience pitting man against beast in the ocean for the film's most spectacular scenes, which are reminiscent of old-school scope of Mutiny on the Bounty and other watery adventures of yesteryear.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The film's greatest strength is its major team-up. Caine and Keitel have an electric chemistry when they're onscreen together ...

Watching Redmayne's character blossom into her true self is remarkable, and the awkwardness getting there only helps make it more relatable to audiences who might not be on board with the subject matter initially.
Leave it to Pixar to go back to the prehistoric age to dig up all your feelings, fossilized and otherwise.
Equally powerful and feel-good, Creed is an entertaining reminder that this franchise isn't down for the count yet.
With terrific acting performances and a bygone era that sparks to life with impressive filmmaking, Carol crafts a memorable romance gift-wrapped for the holiday.
Every journey has to come to a close at some point, and while it's not a perfect exit for Katniss, it's one where she gets to put her bow, arrow and big heart to good use.
True, most Christmas flicks tend toward the trite and predictable naturally, but they just don't have to be quite this insufferable.
No need to bury the lede: Spotlight is a masterpiece.
Craig continues his fine take on the legendary icon of books and movies. His Bond lacks the polish of Roger Moore's and Pierce Brosnan's versions, and for the better.
The movie is both a testament to Charlie Brown's place in pop culture and also a showcase for a new generation bound to fall in love with its perennially insecure star.

The movie unfortunately gets stuck between edgy drama and broad comedy, and most of the humor lands with a thud, unless animals getting run over or an A-list actress mooning bus passengers get your vote.
A lot of the actor's usual mercurial charm isn't used to full effect and is actually tempered when it doesn't feel like it should be.
It's the very definition of meat and potatoes: While not phenomenal, especially compared to the rest of the Spielberg oeuvre, Spies still hits the spot.

While it unabashedly leans into its chick-flick nature, returning director Sharon Maguire - who helmed 2001's franchise-starter Bridget Jones's Diary - manages to craft the strongest and funniest film of the series.
Steve Jobs is a fascinating study of a man, explaining who he was but never making a judgment about who he is. The movie lets audiences compute that for themselves.
Damon totally sells what is arguably his most likable role in years with a balance of charming personality and compelling need to cheer hard for this guy.
For those who want to feel like they're 110 stories up and living in the clouds, Hollywood does its job conjuring movie magic with a breathtaking Walk to remember.
The story isn't even contrived, it's ridiculous.
While there's nothing totally new here, Black Mass works the tropes extremely well and sets the scene early in the mean streets of 1970s South Boston.
Maze Runner's action, suspense and twists give movie fans of all ages a chance to embrace their inner on-the-run teenager.
The low-budget thriller deftly mixes horror-movie moments, pure strangeness and comedy like a family-friendly David Lynch effort as it takes audiences on one really oddball trip to grandma's house.
One doesn't make Jurassic Park without dinosaurs or Fast & Furious without racing cars, so why would anyone in their right mind do a Transporter film without Jason Statham?
A plethora of beats drop but little else of note - musical or otherwise - happens in the Zac Efron DJ fest We Are Your Friends.

McKay utilizes A-list talent and creative filmmaking to go with subprime rates and credit debt, though what it amounts to is the hyper-cool version of a boring economics lesson you slept through in college.
Snowden's a polarizing whistleblower portrayed as an American hero here but in too pedestrian a fashion for such a hot-button topic, and the movie seems at times as awkward as its brainiac subject.
The Hitman's Bodyguard is the comfort food of action comedies, like mac and cheese with a side of extreme violence.
It deals in a world of pawns rather than punches but Queen of Katwe is just as uplifting and feel-good a sports drama as any Rocky movie.

Super-stylish and deeply human - even with androids and holograms around - the spectacular follow-up takes the detective story of the first film and turns it into a grand mythology of identity, memory, creation and revolution.

American Made points out an unfortunate time in our history when government shenanigans ran amok internationally and people did bad things in the name of greed and power. But hoo-boy, does Tom Cruise have fun with it.

Ninjago strongly captures the same manically entertaining and often hilarious nature of its predecessors, though it lacks The Lego Movie's originality and The Lego Batman Movie's commitment to go-for-broke chaos.
While Battle of the Sexes is a reminder of the gender issues still plaguing us, it wholeheartedly embraces the equality of its two excellent leads.

Impending motherhood is seen through a horror-movie lens, there are enough religious metaphors for a particularly strange Sunday school class, and mother! thrives most as a thoughtful and angry look at modern society.
The infamous clown is plenty freaky, though it's the youngsters, bursting with hormones and one-liners, who make It one of the better Stephen King adaptations.
For the cinematic dregs of late August, the earnest and quirky Leap! is charmingly en pointe.
Southern flavor, rampant goofiness and fun twangs go a long way in making director Steven Soderbergh's cinematic return such a sparkling hoot.
The Glass Castle offers up a movie clan to beat in terms of complete dysfunction, though the brutal and heart-wrenching film is in its own way just as much of a mess.
What could have been the next Game of Thrones or The Lord of the Rings is instead more akin to a 1990s Steven Seagal movie (and not one of the good ones).
A chilly air of isolation and desperation pervades the thriller Wind River, Taylor Sheridan's new directorial effort that proves he's more than an exceptional writer.
Wonderstruck works best as half of a great silent film and, with Simmonds, the showcase of a star being born.
Blonde is a new wave-y pretzel of twists on top of twists. It gets a satisfying conclusion, though by then you're wondering if you really knew anything about any of the various players.
Beautiful and deeply affecting, A Ghost Story is easily the greatest movie ever made with an Oscar winner standing around in a white bedsheet for most of its 87-minute runtime.
The magic of Homecoming is that it belongs more to the John Hughes cinematic universe than the Avengers'.
While watching the heartfelt Okja, you'll laugh, you'll cry and you'll definitely rethink that next piece of bacon.
When all cylinders are pumping, Baby Driver is an enchanting experiment that puts the pedal to the metal. And even a few off notes can't stop the beat of Wright's fast and furious symphony.
The satisfying and heart-wrenching climax is a last reminder that Caesar's new adventure is one of this summer's best.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The final act is a non-stop, special-effects bludgeoning of the senses that is zero fun.
The Beguiled showcases good manners and bad deeds, though it lacks the necessary edge to make it a satisfying revenge thriller.
The fuzzy metal handcuffs of raunchy comedies: At times it feels like a good thing but way too often reminds you that you're trapped for an hour and a half.
Some punny lines are painful ... and the plot doesn't even pretend to be unpredictable. But Cars 3 at least tries to put a little extra in the tank this time around.
A tomb full of action-packed guilty pleasure that owns its horror, humor and rampant silliness equally.
A well-crafted, albeit entirely bleak exploration of paranoia and fear.
Nolan's feat is undeniable: He's made an immersive war movie that celebrates the good of mankind while also making it clear that no victory is without sacrifice.
Even tonal issues can't upend the magic this movie taps into putting Thor and Hulk together as new best buddies, whether they're throwing down in an arena or having a bromantic heart-to-heart.
In the grand scheme of Coen brothers' scripts with nimwits making hugely bad decisions, Fargo exists on one brilliant end while Suburbicon lands with a hearty thud somewhere on the other side.

Lady Bird is a perfect coming-of-age comedy for anyone who's ever had teenage wanderlust, fought with their parents, fostered a love-hate tension with their hometown or popped Communion wafers in secret.
If you're looking for something different from the 1960 original - or the movie that was based on, the 1954 classic Seven Samurai - it's best to mosey elsewhere, pilgrim.
The power of love can only do so much in Disney's misbegotten A Wrinkle in Time...across the board, this disappointing Time will cause more than a little wrinkling of the forehead in frustration.
With Cold War tensions arising again in real life, Red Sparrow feels of this time in a cool way, but only Lawrence's spy is memorable in this so-so operation.
On one hand, it's a brainy take on horror tropes, and on the other an empowering female-led mystery with an underlying roller coaster of weird leaving nightmares in its wake.

The film treads familiar ground by pitting a bunch of Davids vs. egotistical Goliaths on the soccer pitch. But it does so in such a supremely quirky and earnestly heartwarming fashion that it's hard not to be charmed.
To her credit, Johnson actually turns in her best Shades stuff here ... Too bad it's not enough to save everything else about this whole silly affair's fumbling climax.
While the themes are deep, Black Panther is at the same time a visual joy to behold, with confident quirkiness, insane action sequences and special effects, and the glorious reveal of Wakanda,
While the final Maze Runner is a rough go at times, it nevertheless sticks the landing, with a forgivable bit of wobble.
Sans magic hammer, Chris Hemsworth's career as a leading man is spotty at best. It seems he just needed horse co-stars.
Words and cards are dealt in equal hand with Aaron Sorkin's poker drama Molly's Game, featuring Jessica Chastain at the center of a compelling film about fame, power and empathy.
Getty's complicated personality is the meat of the matter, and where the movie really does a good job is digging into themes of greed, family and those so rich they think of other people as things.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The show's over. We're pitched out. Aca-exit stage left.
Send in the clowns.
A stellar entry that owes much to George Lucas' original films while finding a signature vibe of its own and unleashing a few welcome twists.
In the grand tapestry of Daniel Day-Lewis' acting career, Phantom Thread will be sewn in as a colorful swatch, though for a retirement role, he leaves us wanting a little more.
An often genius, always subversive film about an outsider who isn't easy to love yet at the same time hard to hate.

The Post is an inspirational reminder of the importance of a free press while unabashedly making journalism look like the most awesome job ever - akin to what Raiders of the Lost Ark did for archaeology.

The scenes that take place in a seemingly undersea world are stunning, and del Toro's filmmaking technique buoys a love-story narrative that at times feels a little too straightforward for its unorthodox conceit.

Director James Franco's enjoyable ode to the creative process - any creative process, really. It's also one of Franco's strongest roles as an actor, capturing every little quirk and quality of a definite eccentric.
The way it explores at length the sweet and sour aspects of first love is worth savoring.
The joyful journey is Pixar's best effort since 2015's Inside Out and, like the studio's greatest works, makes you laugh and cry in equal doses.
Oldman has disappeared into roles before - from Dracula and Beethoven to Sid Vicious and Lee Harvey Oswald - but never so wholly and superbly as in director Joe Wright's Darkest Hour.
With all its overly dramatic head turns and frowny faces, the new Murder largely wastes its extremely impressive cast ...
McDonagh (In Bruges) crafts an expertly structured, brutal, yet surprisingly rousing narrative around a woman who's ready to torch her entire life if it means catching a killer.
Adds star power but unfortunately downshifts the craziness to dive into full Hallmark Channel schmaltz.
Has its share of hilarious moments but never fully commits to the absurd, and even the cleverest jokes get so many callbacks, they're beating a dead seahorse.
The most important lesson from the new Pirates of the Caribbean? Ghost sharks should have been added a long time ago.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Justice League is as solid an outing as any superhero fan could hope, with a clear family vibe: Wonder Woman and Batman prove to be a dynamic mom-and-dad duo while the fastest kid around steals the show.
You hope for a meeting of the talented minds of Trainwreck and Private Benjamin, and just get a trainwreck.
A fabulous old-school Hollywood musical in modern-day Tinseltown with joyous tunes, exceptional choreography, a feel-good love story and a hint of bittersweetness to keep all that wonder grounded.
The iconic first lady is given emotional complexity and rich understanding through a stirring and ambitious performance by Natalie Portman in director Pablo Larrain's powerful drama.

The finale is manipulative in every way, squeezing out the emotions of the audience. But Lion's well-plotted narrative and thoughtful characters suck you in so much that the journey there is totally worth it.

Chastain is scary, chilly, yet extremely likable as the hard-charging insider. In meetings and on the job, she has no filter, though as the movie progresses, the actress shows necessary cracks in her character's cold exterior.
Tries so hard to be a modern Casablanca - and then imagine what the tale would be like if Rick and Ilsa actually got together - that it shoots down a lot of its finer points.
A solid if unspectacular effort, though Beatty smartly takes a supporting role to the youngsters by playing the kookily eccentric Hughes.
Nocturnal Animals is at its core about making hard decisions and living through the inevitable consequences, though told with some serious artistic flash.
Manchester by the Sea is a deeply affecting and wickedly funny masterpiece showcasing the maturation of men, from the broken man and his nephew at its heart to the drama's phenomenal filmmaker.
Whether you're a Potterhead or not, Beasts creates a story that's both original and enchanting.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Saddled with an inconsistent plot, maudlin melodrama and surprising cynicism about the heroism of young soldiers coming home from war.
So what if she'd rather be a sailor than a princess? Moana still rules.
Even an underwhelming Star Wars is a pretty decent Star Wars, but Rogue One misses a real chance to turn the familiar into something remarkable.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Arrival is such a beautiful and thought-provoking film that it almost singlehandedly makes up for every bad aliens-coming-to-Earth film you've ever seen.
As he did so well in Braveheart, Gibson explores the reasons men fight for their country rather than just reveling in blood and gore.
Even with a wealth of talent involved, Inferno is missing some serious heat.
A kaleidoscope of weirdness and innovative visual effects successfully introduce the newest Marvel superhero in director/co-writer Scott Derrickson's brilliantly bizarre Doctor Strange.
A major step backward with an A-list actor in a C-grade military thriller.
Where The Accountant really succeeds is exploring the emotions and coping mechanisms of a protagonist on the autism spectrum, plot points not often seen in the macho action genre.
The major whodunit here is who made a best-selling thriller so darn boring.
A work this powerful would be impressive for any filmmaker, so the fact that this is Parker's first directorial feature is undoubtedly amazing.
After a long run of dystopian YA movies for teen crowds, Burton is just the right guy to make cinema weird again.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard not to feel the gritty rescue scenes, be mesmerized by the flammable carnage or get belatedly enraged by the idiocy of oil-company bureaucracy.
Covenant does succeed in continuing Prometheus' ambition to deepen the Alien mythology with a meaning-of-life bent.
Good news, parents: Storks is bound to entertain you and your little ones. Bad news: Get ready to answer a lot more awkward questions about where babies come from.
You'd be hard-pressed to keep from smiling throughout the trippy dance sequences and clever banter in this feel-good confection.
With the level of acting talent involved, Fences could have been filmed in the parking lot of a pet store and still been just as effective.
The real artistry of Loving ... is in the quiet grace Negga and Edgerton bring to one of recent history's most important romances.
In a year full of talking-animal hits, Sing isn't quite as strong a number. It's a tale that might not be particularly thought-provoking but sure is toe-tapping.
A sharp-tongued swing and a miss at the tale of the Knights of the Round Table.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Just like the first one, Guardians of the Galaxy Vol. 2 is a winning and wonderfully relatable gem of crazy.
With the religious historical drama Silence, Martin Scorsese proves he's as masterful a filmmaker with men of God as he is with gangsters.
Free Fire is a fun romp for those missing a little Quentin Tarantino-style insanity in their filmgoing lives.
Your mileage may vary when it comes to the over-the-top carnage and in-your-face machismo, but it's impressive just how bonkers Fate is, like a litter of kittens hopped up on grade-A catnip.
Colossal is as refreshingly different a monster movie as it is a clever, timely take on bullying, domestic abuse and toxic masculinity.
Everybody shows their work in the winning math of Gifted, which finds a simple formula for success with a flawed father figure and his prodigious niece.

Despite the beautiful eye-popping world it creates, the sci-fi film Ghost in the Shell is a defective mess with lifeless characters, missed chances for thematic exploration and a minefield of political incorrectness.
Hope you take your Zords with a large helping of cheese.
Kong still commands respect ... his presence alone makes it worth a trip to Skull Island.
Beauty and the Beast marries visual spectacle and sumptuous design work with a better story than its original, casting a spell on old fans and newcomers alike.

While Before I Fall might not be for every grown-up - for starters, those put off by the word "bae"- it does work for teens looking for authenticity and a high-concept story that reflects their insular world.
Peele has written a script that is extremely well-paced and executed as it cleverly plays with allusions to slavery and racial stereotypes, as well as audience expectations.
It's far from perfect, but Life's worth living for two freaky hours.
The Founder has its flaws - though not as many as its main subject - yet is an insightful look at the history of an iconic institution that doubles as a cautionary tale.
A haphazard, albeit mostly entertaining tale of tommy gunners and rum runners.
Easily the best Wolverine outing, Logan is The Dark Knight of the mutant-filled X-franchise, a gripping film that transcends the comic-book genre by saying something important ...
In other hands, Patriots Day could have been a paint-by-the numbers action thriller, but strong performances and well-paced momentum make it an engrossing watch.
An eerie and intimate psychological thriller with Hitchcockian tones harkening back to the Shyamalan's early 2000s run that put him on the filmmaking map.
Nothing in Gold is quite golden, though at least Matthew McConaughey - with a lack of hair and an abundance of beer gut - shines.
A Monster Calls dials up a nostalgic and superb coming-of-age journey that'll have audiences grabbing all the hankies.
The whole sci-fi narrative collapses into a mess of illogical story beats and groan-inducing quasi-tragic bits right out of Love Story.
The not-so-Dark Knight returns in the joyously bonkers The Lego Batman Movie, and he's not only the hero we need right now but also the one we deserve.
Somehow manages to be worse than the stupefyingly bad Fifty Shades of Grey.
The Great Wall would probably be a lot more culturally offensive if it wasn't such a complete trainwreck.
Adding social issues to its many inspirational themes, Hidden Figures equals one satisfying slice of history that'll entertain adults as well as kids looking to the stars.
A relentless two-hour assault both on the eardrums and the eyeballs, Mad Max: Fury Road is the craziest film of the year so far -- and one of the loudest of all time.
Helgeland ... believes too much in his title.

It is Depp's show, and once you stop being distracted by the efforts of the make-up department - which give him a high forehead, drastically slicked-back hair and the faint air of a visitor from outer space - his portrayal is utterly riveting.

Like both its leads, the film is a pleasure to look at. Twenties Copenhagen, and later Paris, are evoked with a painterly eye by the director and his regular collaborator, cinematographer Danny Cohen. But in a way that's part of the problem.
As fine as the cast is (with Knightley turning in a small but genuinely affecting performance), the film's stand-out star is right there in the title.
If it's true that we get the comedies we deserve, we must have been a considerably more deserving lot 32 years ago.
The film is as soulless as Agent 47 is, conforming to all the mediocre-thriller cliches (the action zips from Salzburg to Berlin to Singapore for next to no coherent reason) with little originality.

It is properly, hilariously inspired, and if this film can be classified as silent comedy, which I think it can despite all the grunts and squeaks in place of dialogue, then it deserves to be ranked with the best of Charlie Chaplin and Buster Keaton.

I went with low-ish expectations, which for the first 20 minutes or so showed every sign of being met as one dude yo-duded another dude, only for the film to win me round, rather, with its sheer energy.
You don't need sound and fury to create an emotional maelstrom.
Fontaine's picture is fatally underwrought, with Arterton unable to invest in her character any quality that makes us care about her even a fraction as much as the men bewitched by her.
Weird as these boys are, and as their story is, Moselle's film is nothing but affectionate, and I found myself falling for their rather sweet unworldliness just as she obviously did.
Nolte is terrific insofar as he is allowed to be, but what ensues is, cinematically, a mess.
Genius is an over-used and therefore devalued word, but Inside Out is what it looks like.
A quirkily engaging, sporadically very funny comedy.
The film is sumptuously shot, lit, scored and acted.
You feel as if you have sat through a modestly interesting picture under mostly false pretences.
If it does not sound like quite enough to sustain an audience's interest, that is because it isn't. But it might have been.
It's terrific entertainment.
Kurzel makes full use of his medium, which can't be said of all cinematic adaptations of Shakespeare plays.

A fascinating film, funny and at times properly moving.
Maybe it was because I already know the story so well that I never felt fully engaged.

I counted at least half a dozen people leaving before this film was even half-way through, including children who were audibly trying to reconcile the spectacle on screen with the animated Disney version they know so well.

From the exhilarating pre-credits sequence, against the backdrop of the Day of the Dead festival in Mexico City, to a spectacular denouement in the shadow of the Houses of Parliament, Spectre is a proper joyride of a James Bond film.
Jake Gyllenhaal is tremendous in the boxing tale Southpaw. The movie? Not so much. It's the best performance I've seen in a bad movie since Julianne Moore won an Oscar for Still Alice.

A minor classic ... maybe just a touch too sentimental towards the end, but a compelling celebration of male friendship all the same, with a blues soundtrack to be treasured, and a pair of lead performances worthy of awards.
No film suffers from a lack of originality alone but there are too many other contrivances here, above all that intense brand of middle-aged, middle-class female buddyship that exists only on screen.

On the whole this is dismal fare ...
Acted on me as all good horror films should, generating that prickly shiver through the shoulders and into the neck.

Slick but shamelessly derivative.

It's fascinating, disturbing stuff.

A film that does not so much scream as bludgeon its debt to American Psycho and The Wolf Of Wall Street, without being remotely as good as either.
A resounding misfire.
At last, and in fine if rather oppressive style, the end of The Hunger Games saga comes into sight.
It is saddled with the kind of script that doubtless created no end of belly laughs in an office in West Hollywood, but yields rather fewer in the cinema.
For all the sporadic giggles, it's impossible to avoid the conclusion that this is a one-note joke that has been stretched too far.
Behind all the glibness, all the gore, Deadpool is actually a rather poignant romance. I quite liked it, although it's not nearly as funny as its debutant director Tim Miller seems to think it is.

Po the chubby panda and his fellow anthromorphs return for another exhilaratingly silly DreamWorks adventure, this time with a formidable new villain to vanquish, in the form of Kai, an enormous, snorting, bull-like creature from the Chinese spirit world.

A terrific documentary directed by Mark Craig and executive-produced by Sir Jackie Stewart, among others.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Williams could exude charisma on screen like almost nobody else, but here he just exudes sorrowful introspection.

movie_review_blurb: Almost unwatchably feeble.
It's Wiig's show, in more ways than one.
Full of mild pleasures.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You'd expect a few giggles from so much comedic talent, and there are some, but in the laughs department, as in most others, Cedric Nicolas-Troyan's film seems to be straining too hard.

movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

There isn't a single lesson I am taking away other than the obviousness of Eli Roth's desire to shock people as much as he possibly can, and a reminder that money talks.
Less than the sum of its parts. There are too many small errors and lost opportunities, and it's just not scary. Even a B movie can't succeed when that's the case.
Creates real tension, and as long as you can live with 1940s-style special effects, this is a reasonably effective war movie from the unique perspective of army nurses.
Filled with head scratchingly dumb twists and cornball dialogue, this is not exactly a brilliant film. Yet it's got a slick look and at least a few passable action scenes.
movie_title: The Death and Life of Bobby Z (1982)

movie_review_blurb: A light piffle of a movie, not particularly complex, certainly not tense, and not a laugh riot either. But don't get me wrong - this is a pleasant film.
In continuing to move the movie series forward with new ideas that don't lack respect for the old, they've made Bond relevant to a new generation.
A decent film that doesn't occupy a single neat genre category, and often doesn't seem able to decide who it's trying to speak to.
We need to remind ourselves that Hollywood makes dreck like this for the same reason that caterpillars lay a zillion eggs.
Sometimes accused of failing to harness the kinetic energy that abounds in his films, Martin Scorsese has done such a fine job of balancing the heat and the cold here.
Think of Groundhog Day with guns and car chases. And without humour.
Sofia Coppola has sacrificed a compelling storyline in exchange for aimless atmospherics.
Leaves out too much of the story to really work. Why are these people doing what they're doing? If I hadn't seen the 1949 version first, I would not have known.
Smart, interesting to look at, and courageous, this is one of the best films of 2006.
Of zero interest to true horror movie fans, and certainly will bore those looking for quality cinema. It will, however, provide a giggle or two to bad movie aficionados.
It continues to use secondary characters brilliantly, allowing them to add depth and humour to the proceedings.
Mike White has had the courage to redirect his abundant quirkiness away from benign nerdiness and toward a quiet subversiveness.
Rather talky, but a reasonably solid cop show and a neat little window onto the world of 1960s America.
While parallels with the Iraq situation are unmistakeable, it's more concerned with terrifyingly dismal atmosphere and a kinetic, intense race for survival.
It's the smart dialogue and plain old darn witty ideas at the core of this film that lift it above the average Hollywood comedy.
An empty shell of a film, devoid of heart and soul, leaving us to wonder how in the world this movie ever got released.
Exciting and compelling, but even more than that, it's a great acting showcase for Leonardo DiCaprio and Djimon Hounsou.
The 1980s were not a particularly inspired era, so it's appropriate that a middling romantic comedy like this one would earn the title of quintessential movie of the decade.
Smart, fascinating and horrifying, All the King's Men is an example of late 1940s filmmaking at its best.
Along with some good laughs, there's also a bit of effective tension.
Appeals equally to fans of no-holds-barred gross-out movies and those looking for something more intelligent. It's hilarious, surprisingly perceptive, and even sweet.
Paul Muni goes way over the top as Tony Camonte, painting a picture of a gangster who knows nothing but excess, and who will stop at nothing to get his way.
Shrek has been great fun. Now let's say goodbye and move on to some fresher ideas.
How can we be inspired by the spirit of Jaguar Paw when the film's telling us that people stink and the great cultures of the Americas were the architects of their own demise?
After a great set-up, we're left stranded by the side of the road, wishing the filmmakers had come up with a conclusion at least somewhere close to as good.
Brutal, senseless, depraved %u2013 but most of all, dumber than dumb - Death Sentence most certainly is complete and total flapdoodle.
Filled with emotional pain, it's a perceptive, truthful film interested not in passing judgement, but rather in exploring the truth about relationships, pregnancy and life.
It's refreshing to see images that are uncommon in mainstream kids movies, especially when this Chinese creativity is so full of colour and vitality.
Even if you are rooting for this film to succeed, you find yourself sitting through the tear-jerking part of the movie without feeling terribly wrapped up in it.
The astonishing sensitivity with which Richard Jenkins approaches his role is nicely complimented by the performances of other cast members.
Even if you share my substantial concerns over what it says about American society today, you'll find it difficult to dislike this razor sharp, wry and troubling show.
The makings of an uncompromising, razor sharp satire were gathered together here. That the resulting movie slips off track as much as it does is particularly disappointing.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: How do you sum up a movie that's really quite awful yet helped define a filmmaking era?
The story's impact is reduced by the filmmakers' decision to make everyone who is part of 'the system' not just complicit in the conspiracy, but also lacking humanity.
It's as if the filmmakers are too nervous about making a mistake, so consistently take the safe path, draining the movie of colour and leaving us sympathetic but uninspired.
For those of us who want movies to be about something and not just empty action with minimal shallow 'moral of the story' tacked on, Body of Lies is a disappointment.
This is a quirky, often quite sardonic little film that starts off as a mild and witty comedy before shifting gears and becoming almost James Bond-like.
We are saddled with the limitations of the 'found' film premise - seemingly endless screaming and scrabbling around in the dark, filmed from just a single angle.
Memorable both for its spoofing of a wacky combination of Elvis movies, spy movies and Second World War intrigue films and for the fact that it's Val Kilmer's film debut.
Fascinates us in an almost perverse way, gripping us with its tension, thrilling us with its action, and troubling us with its dystopic view of American society circa 1971.
I am no great fan of sequels, and am especially suspicious of movies that try to cross-over between adult and child audiences. But this one won me over early on.
If you take away comparisons with the original, it's a reasonably solid, if flawed, crime thriller; but it does shrink into the shadow cast by its vastly superior predecessor.
Exhibits many of the genre's common weaknesses, but the fine acting of Edward Norton, Laura Linney and Richard Gere enables us to forgive them.
Reminds us of how truly brilliant filmmaking needs none of the technology and bombast Hollywood has come to depend on.
Burdened by a cliche-ridden burnt-out-cop movie screenplay and over-the-top performances that don't mesh, this is a thriller that doesn't thrill as much as it irritates.
Jonathan Demme has struck a brilliant balance here, delivering a film that looks, sounds and feels painfully honest, while making it entertaining as well as deeply truthful.
If it wasn't following such an excellent 21st Bond movie, it would be considered a big step forward. Instead, it'll settle for the more modest label of "another good one."
While it's no crowd-pleaser, Frozen River is powerfully honest stripped-down filmmaking.
Interesting in many ways, like its director (Arch Oboler), Five falls short of really hitting home.
Filled with likeable characters, smart dialogue and cool indie music, it's good natured, hilarious and an outstanding romantic comedy that makes you wish you could be there.
Against all odds, the presence of the incomparable Julia Roberts makes this a damn enjoyable career-defining film for Garry Marshall, and a guilty pleasure for movie lovers.
Tom Cruise's ego-driven "Look at me; aren't I heroic?" performance detracts, but it's just too compelling and the other performances too pitch-perfect for this to ruin things.
Certainly passable, but less than spectacular, Brideshead Revisited is an authentic and decent adaptation of a well-known novel, but nothing more.
An ideal platform for writer/ director Clint Eastwood to show the world that, at 78 years of age, he's at the top of his game.
With bland protagonists and power figures unpleasant enough for us to want them out of our sight more than we want them defeated, it doesn't do much to hold our interest.
It's likely that few people will ever even notice the success it might have been or the unremarkable failure it turned out to be.
In addition to being fascinating and exciting, City of Ember invites its young viewers to constantly ask questions and never give up.
A handful of TV series have moved from lengthy small screen runs to the big screen; few can match The X-Files in consistent quality and ability to engage its audience.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: I hope nobody misunderstands when I say: Steve Martin, you are no Peter Sellers. And while I'm at it; Shawn Levy, you are no Blake Edwards.
It's hard to say harsh things about a movie as earnest and well intentioned as Gospel Hill. But we've got to do what we've got to do, now, don't we?
Dumb title? Certainly. Perfectly proportioned? Nope. True-to-life? Certainly not. An enjoyably quirky indie comedy? You bet.
While it's been a long time since I trashed the original Stargate movie, I must say that this latest incarnation leaves me about equally cold.
Now and again, the humour is quite effective and the spoof of RV road warriors hits the mark, but more often, the jokes are higher on energy than they are on laugh generation.
As a thriller, it's passable, but at what point do we say to director Neil LaBute, "Enough already with the misogynistic themes"?
If you hear someone deriding Superbad for being unoriginal or derivative, sit them in front of College. If they can't tell the difference, they're a lost cause.
Arguably, it already seemed dated by the early 1970s, within a decade of its 1964 release. Yet still, somehow, the substantial charms of Mary Poppins live on.
This is a movie by and for the actors, especially for Kate Winslet, whose prodigious talents are well used throughout this bleak, troubling and powerful drama.
When we should be feeling fascinated by the unfolding mystery and creeped out by things acting up nastily, we instead find ourselves thinking too much and asking questions.
If you think Eddie Murphy lost his mojo about 20 years ago and has been lacking clear comedic judgment ever since, then you've got to see this for confirmation. Or maybe not.
Ask ten people who've seen this movie what the title's "miracle" is referring to, and you'll get a couple of different guesses and a whole lot of blank stares and shrugs.
More notable for what it isn't than what it is, it's one of the gangly middle children of the Disney animation family, not quite sure how to fit in, or even if it's valued.
It's as if director Fernando Meirelles got so wrapped up in the desolation of his story that he neglected to do anything meaningful with it.
A clumsily melodramatic movie that tells us too much too soon and forces us to sit through endless morose vacuousness.
Sometimes seems to be overwhelmed by Baz Luhrmann's excess, but the strength of his vision, the appeal of his visuals and the skill of his actors keep the film from capsizing.
Few actors could have pulled off this role successfully, as it requires great energy, charisma and depth to make Poppy credible and so much more than first impressions.
When the time comes for resolution, writer/ director Mark Herman suddenly delivers the unexpected; he does not sell out.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While I admire filmmakers who navigate material like this without sentimentality, this film stands back just a bit too much and leaves us feeling like distant observers.
Clearly, writer/director Greg Mottola has plenty of good ideas and an inclination toward quirky movies just slightly off-centre.
The sort of movie that folks who are addicted to a Tom Cruise-style action sequence every three minutes might dismiss as one in which "nothing happens."
Like Arctic Tale, this is a great looking and interesting view of nature. Also like that other 2007 film, Earth falls short of being truly memorable.
Like Arctic Tale, this is a great looking and interesting view of nature. Also like that other 2007 film, Earth falls short of being truly memorable.
This is both an entertaining old movie and a significant historical document. If you love film, then you must see Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs.
movie_title: Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937)

movie_review_blurb: The 1970s-style special effects do little to distract us from an uneven script, direction and performances. Yet there's enough here for us to hope it'll come together.
Clearly, one person's authentic homage is another person's overwrought teeth-gnashing fest, as Branagh's film never hesitates to slop on the melodramatic mustard.
Scene after scene unfolds, with colourful costumes, attractive sets, knowing glances and innuendo, but also a feeling that this is a pedestrian read-through of a stage play.
It's not awful, certainly not memorable and - despite the words of at least one quote whore - it's not "the year's best comedy."
I'm mystified by those who find these characters appealing.
movie_title: Ice Age: Dawn of the Dinosaurs (Ice Age 3) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A joyous, wacky, sometimes bittersweet story of love, loss and making your dreams come true, Up does what Pixar movies usually do %u2013 it far exceeds our expectations.
You can watch Bruno purely as outrageousness or you can view it while pondering where the line is - or should be - between incisive social commentary and misanthropy.
Mike Judge's nuggets are often enjoyable enough for us to want to ignore the fact that Extract really doesn't work particularly well in its totality.
Peter Jackson is anything but a good fit to direct this story, as his well-intentioned efforts at conveying transcendence sometimes look and feel phony.
Sure, it's made capably, in a technical sense. But it's banal, utterly predictable and often quite stupid.
If you've got the slightest interest in Jackson's music, then this is the movie for you. If you want to learn the truth about the icon, then you're looking at the wrong film.
Funny, eccentric and great-looking, Fantastic Mr. Fox is utterly unique and highly entertaining.
I never thought the day would come where I'd wish I were watching Scooby-Doo rather than what's actually onscreen.
movie_title: Alvin and the Chipmunks: The Squeakquel (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The result is a pretty standard old-style Disney story -- of damsel up against exotic challenges -- that's very nicely spiced up by its unique setting.
Has a goofy and over-the-top way of making its point, but as long as you're not stuck on it fitting a particular mould, it's a fun - and meaningful - ride.
Even without the bad timing %u2013 a paean to debt and excess released a few months after the world's biggest financial meltdown since the 1920s %u2013 it still would not have worked.
Goes for cheap laughs with its politics, but wins back at least some respect when it presents its central characters as real people and their issues as immune to instant cure.
Promotes the classic American ethos of individualism without seeming preachy or narrow-minded, creating characters we enjoy, a story that's fun and visuals that sparkle.
Makes you wish the makers - and especially the funders - of today's overblown big budget thrillers could be made to learn from some of the finer thrillers of the 1970s.
I'm all for scepticism over the latest 'hot' movie; the really great ones effortlessly blow such scepticism out of the water. This film most certainly does that.
So much fun, you might be tempted to conclude that Disney's acquisition of the amazing Pixar team has inspired the already in-house Disney team to new heights.
The acting talent in evidence here is astounding and nobody, absolutely nobody puts her or his performance ahead of everyone else.
Given that Sandler's main appeal has always been to the 12-year-old in all of us, it probably makes sense for him to aim his movies directly at that age group.
The conclusion transforms at least this part of the film from sappy romance to beautifully authentic meditation on life, death and a family's love for its long-time loyal dog.
It amounts to less than the sum of its artfully conceived parts but remains a nice and visually interesting film.
By risking the alienation of formula fans, screenwriter Paul Haggis and director Tony Goldwyn have taken a chance and given us a small gift.
The sort of movie that will do a perfectly acceptable job of filling an evening that otherwise might be empty (or, God forbid %u2013 one that cries out for reading a good book).
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Clearly the work of a mature filmmaker, one with the patience and self confidence to make a smart film whose success is largely in the hands of its talented cast.
Screenwriters and directors can turn to this classic film for a primer on how to create incredible tension and horror far in excess of what we actually see onscreen.
If you are going to see only one Peter Sellers movie, see Dr. Strangelove, but if you're going to see two, then Being There also belongs on your must-see list.
It's just plain lazy (or incompetent or both) filmmaking from start to finish.
Filmmakers have the power to change reality on us at their whim, but if they do so in ways that make us feel tricked and cheated, then this is an unforgiveable rip-off.
Topping off an outstanding production, director Darren Aronofsky's ending to The Wrestler is sheer perfection.
Like April weather most places north of the Mediterranean, this one is lukewarm, at best.
The quintessential teen comedy, this is a movie that could and should serve as a model for movies of this sort in the future.
What's most disappointing here is that Kevin James appears capable of far more rich and subtle comedy than he's ever likely to be part of in a Happy Madison production.
It's difficult to call a movie this light and insubstantial a classic, but it's as likeable as ever more than two decades after its initial release.
This film looks good, is capably acted and builds excellent atmosphere. And then it gets lost, and so do we.
Might not be musical enough for some, and it's certainly not going to be substantial enough for some. But it's entertaining and more emotionally true than you might expect.
It's got all the attributes of a guilty pleasure - excitement, some undeniably enjoyable scenes and the absence of what it needs to be more memorable and more substantial.
That Edward Zwick made such an honest film about the Bielski brothers is a wonderful gift, even if it is likely to be underappreciated by audiences.
Dark cinema, but also perceptive and revelatory in exploring how an ill-fated couple struggles to cope with tragedy.
A fascinating tall tale until the incredible Tilda Swinton appears, vulnerable, full of regrets and compelling us to start thinking, but from then on, this is a tour de force.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While there's nothing remarkable about the way director Gary Fleder has brought The Express to the screen, this is a solid film that does justice to Davis' legacy.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Shake Hands with the Devil: The Journey of Romeo Dallaire (2005)

movie_review_blurb: While it's most certainly not light viewing, and it's entirely devoid of 'Hollywood moments', this is a fine, intelligent, troubling film.
Reflects a conservative, imperialist, 'don't mix the races/species' worldview. Yet it's also about friendship and truthfulness, and it's just plain fun.
The biggest problem with this film is that Mack Polhemus lined up members of his family to play most of the key roles. And, frankly, they can't act.
The story includes too many twists, resulting in a sense of contrivance by film's end. Yet this is still a decent, serious film that's capably directed and very nicely acted.
Works both as a tense thriller (complete with a skilfully handled time twist), and as an urgent warning about the track the world is currently on.
Just another supernatural time travel movie that lacks passion and seemingly evaporates even as you watch.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: There are enough really funny scenes to more than make up for the obnoxiousness and humourless stretches. Not exactly the ringing endorsement you'd hope for.
Both an enjoyable call-back to the early '70s and a well-acted film that gives Richard Gere a chance to fully exhibit his acting skills.
Sydney White isn't incompetently made. It's not even particularly offensive. It's just very, very uninspired and almost instantly forgettable.
Like the characters populating it, this film leaves us with a sense that something is missing, but it's still smart, compelling, offbeat, and worth seeing.
Flops because it lacks true tension and certainly can't keep up with the shock value of its gore-filled horror contemporaries.
Shows some significant strengths but ultimately misses the mark due to incompletely developed characters and hesitation to hit home as hard as the subject matter justifies.
Neither perceptive nor authentic, it lacks genuine humour and shows what an overwritten and under-funny script, put in the hands of immature actors, can produce.
You'd be hard pressed to find a movie that's sexier, or sadder. It's a tragic film that's highly successful as both a wartime thriller and a tale of doomed love
Has numerous levels that go far beyond a whodunit, asking us to look at familial ties, gender roles and relations, and the interactions of military and civilian worlds.
Let's call this one 'Vampire Movies for Dummies', complete with our hero (John Hartnett) having the job of solemnly stating the obvious as a pseudo narrator.
Simply a curiosity, a laughable relic of a failed effort to bring explicit sex movies to the masses.
Pleasant but insubstantial, and with characters whose eccentricities feel just a tad forced and artificial, this is a mild diversion of a film.
Is it dramatically worse than other run-of-the-mill horror/mysteries? Nope. But that's hardly a ringing endorsement.
Its pessimistic view of the future is as old hat as the superhero premise, but the way it looks most certainly is not. Style over substance? Certainly. But what style!
Once the shooting goes quiet it reminds us of the futility of all the violence and hate. But only after our heroes have bagged themselves a goodly number of terrorist scum.
I'm tempted to suggest it was made for 13-year-old boys, but I remember being 13, and I'd have been offended if anyone had suggested movies this awful were made for me.
Everything about this competently made but utterly hollow movie is exactly what you'd expect, even if you haven't seen either of its predecessors.
There are fragments of good comedy packed amidst the many forgettable scenes that you've seen a dozen times before in a dozen other forgettable comedies
The film looks professional and has a relatively big-name star in Gillian Anderson, but the screenplay - written by director Dan Reed - doesn't make a single bit of sense.
The film looks professional and has a relatively big-name star in Gillian Anderson, but the screenplay - written by director Dan Reed - doesn't make a single bit of sense.
While often both funny and perceptive, it's less than memorable, and a weak ending reduces it to more of a time-filler than a movie that's truly worthwhile.
The biggest weakness of Bordertown is its heavy-handed over-simplification of complex political and economic issues. That and Jennifer Lopez's massive ego.
Exciting, looks great, and even with the heavy emphasis on gunplay and action, it's well acted, especially by Christian Bale.
Has little to offer other than laughs at its campiness, and a reminder of how low budget filmmaking by those with higher aspirations looked, back in the day.
Rarely awful, Garry Marshall's films consistently exhibit a veneer of banality, and Georgia Rule is no exception.
Standard romantic comedy, but it's done so nicely, and is sufficiently spiced up by an unusual what-am-I-really-watching? storytelling device, that it rises above its genre.
It's spirited, totally exploitative, entirely forgettable high body count slasher movie fun, and it sure ain't pretending to be quality cinema.
The Brave One might have been honest, perceptive, and troubling. Instead, it becomes aimless revenge porn.
Immersed in cynicism and dark humour, this movie wins us over early on and then holds our attention with a compelling story and a trio of interesting central characters.
A well-meaning but bland and shallow salute to Selena.
A sentimental, simplistically inspiring movie that leans heavily on Matthew McConaughey's substantial energy and charisma for its success.
In addition to Carly Schroeder's performance, the highlights are its honesty, willingness to show real family struggles, and the gradual way Gracie achieves success.
Will this be a memorable series people talk about 25 years later? Hardly likely.
Was it insensitive to make this film when it stood to represent the gay subculture to mainstream America? Yes. Is it a great film? No. But it is a fascinating relic.
Beautifully filmed, brutally frank, and forceful in its political message - in support of active peacekeeping - this is a powerful film that's not to be missed.
Punctuated by numerous graphic - and highly erotic - sex scenes, Green Chair is an unusual and ultimately convincing love story.
Its failings are substantial, yet the fact that it's overblown and incredible doesn't entirely outweigh the fact that it's also exciting, fascinating, sexy, and thrilling.
Verging on 'so bad it's fun to watch' territory, I Witness doesn't quite make it there either.
Given Sarah Silverman's style - smart, taboo-challenging, rude and non-conformist - it's no surprise that her television sit-com is something of an acquired taste.
Cute and witty, if a bit too dependent on its delightfully goofy storyline gimmick.
As with many icons, the substance amounts to much less than its familiarity, but this is still worthwhile entertainment of an escapist, light and nostalgic sort.
Well intentioned, spectacularly filmed, and packing a vital message, Arctic Tale is worthwhile, even if its old style presentation leaves us less than thrilled.
A witty, visually interesting and sweet comedy that works in pretty much all departments.
Not about high profile characters or big action, it delights by entertaining and inspiring more subtly. Who expected that from any movie these days, let alone an animated one?
Impressive to look at, but in the end, it just doesn't ring true.
movie_title: The Messenger: The Story of Joan of Arc (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Even with its excess and undeniably heavy hand, this is a whole lot of fun as a satire of Hollywood, a take off on war/ action flicks and as a straight-ahead action movie.
It's unfair to characterize it as Lord of the Rings-Light, but it's difficult to avoid that conclusion after watching this earnest but seriously under-inspired effort.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Only occasionally funny and about three times as long as the material justifies, it's boring and just a little bit embarrassing to sit through.
Some of Will Ferrell's biggest fans might find it overly tame and subtle, but it's interesting, enjoyable and a revelation to see he can keep his pants on and still entertain.
Fascinating and horrifying, especially if you take a step back and view it thinking about what it tells us about the society in which these abuses took place.
By making the choices the filmmakers did here, we get a movie that may not be profound, but it's both highly entertaining for its sports and fascinating for its social issues.
Taking on Seuss has proven a challenge for Hollywood, but a nice balance has been struck here between authenticity and new ideas. This one's a winner.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: How anyone ever thought there was more than one movie in the Mummy concept, I don't know.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not funny, not sexy, not even obnoxious enough to get anyone worked up, The House Bunny truly establishes a new low water mark for 2008 cinema.
Dustin Hoffman is subtly brilliant, Emma Thompson is tremendous, and writer/ director Joel Hopkins deserves our thanks for creating such a gentle, wonderful film.
More an inconsistent collection of gags and skits than a cohesive feature, but the highs are funny and the lows hard to get worked up about, so we still walk away smiling.
Doesn't take full advantage of the opportunity offered by a year-long glimpse into young lives. One is left to wonder what Errol Morris would have done with the challenge.
Lowest-common-denominator filmmaking at its most discouraging, with makers who believe moviegoers too stupid to think, so instead opt for constant adrenal gland stimulation.
Deserves credit for playing things straight %u2013 complete with its moral quagmire and inherent sadness. The performances of Knightley, Fiennes and Atwell really make it work.
While it's true that romantic comedy is to fine film what a burger and fries is to gourmet dining, David Koepp has shown here that his directorial skills are considerable.
This is not just another hodgepodge of a movie that's all noise and excess; writer/ director Richard Kelly has a point here; he has plenty to say.
It's like getting two movies for the price of one %u2013 light romantic comedy and a relatively effective human drama at the same time.
The story is predictably pedestrian, the conflict laughable and the dialogue too lifeless to be laughable, but closer to that than convincing or compelling.
Rather than enhancing the franchise, Shrek the Halls is a dispiriting holiday cash cow.
The story is interesting, in a twisted fairytale sort of way, but the novelty of this dream world does eventually wear off, and we're left checking our watches.
Without Anne Hathaway, Get Smart might have been a one-note comedy; with her, it's super spirited and super fun.
A great-looking, colourful old-style classic.
Quote not available.
If you're prepared to sit through a lot of mediocrity in search of a few worthwhile moments and a couple of actors who rise above the material, then you might be satisfied.
If you're looking for something a little bit offbeat, Penelope won't send you diving out any windows to escape its quirky humour and gentle moralizing.
Less than profound, but consistently honest, Things We Lost in the Fire is neither triumphant nor great, but it is meaningful.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Michael Haneke has made a film that's neither smart nor powerful, but instead just miserable and disrespectful of its audience, and nothing more.
Sean Penn deserves huge credit for the gentle hand he has used in telling this incredible story.
A nice-enough Disney feature that some consider an under-appreciated classic and others view as a movie that's distinguished only by the inclusion of a handful of cool jazz tunes.
Writer/ director Peter Hedges likes to touch on deeper emotional truths, but he doesn't have the courage to really probe his characters' struggles in a meaningful way.
Sweet, perceptive, sharp and near-perfect, Juno is a memorable film that will still be great viewing decades after its release.
Without a particularly strong storyline and loaded with only modestly enjoyable gags, it putts along like a familiar old jalopy, reasonably likeable if eminently forgettable.
It may not win over diehard Disney haters, and it doesn't qualify as great filmmaking, but I bet kids will be enjoying this one for decades to come.
A skilfully made and subtly powerful film, with a disarmingly human protagonist whose efforts seem all the more real, given his weaknesses and the movie's authentic feel.
Retains the Coen brothers' trademark quirkiness, and it certainly goes all out. But it's also subtle in ways we haven't seen before.
Burton took on a risky proposition when he chose to bring Sweeney Todd to the screen. While the result doesn't knock my socks off, it's plenty good enough to report that the risk paid off.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The story nicely interweaves the legend of the Loch Ness monster with a tale of childhood angst, wartime drama and adventure.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Awfully uneven, sometimes not funny at all, but John C. Reilly is so goofily sincere and Jake Kasdan and Judd Apatow include enough comedic gems to make it worthwhile.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While director Jerry Zucker seems to have been intent on dragging the film to the mushy middle, it's still more entertaining than most comparable Middle Ages-set movies.
Regardless of what one thinks of David Lean and his old fashioned style, the results here - save perhaps for the casting of Alec Guinness as a Hindu professor - are exquisite.
Featuring one of the most complex and interesting lead characters you will ever find in the movies, Paul Thomas Anderson's film marks a big step forward for the director.
