Sweet songs inspired by the Jazz Era setting, a happy story and a heroine with ambition; this is Disney as I remember it and now your children can too.
Clearly fascinated by the power of new technology and the fact that anyone is able to broadcast their thoughts, Egoyan has made an engrossing movie with an intriguing, original plot.

If you are going to bring a victim of this magnitude to the screen, give her history the treatment it deserves, ie good direction or at the very least some proper editing to serve as an emotional sat-nav.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Gibson has always given good cop, and in Edge of Darkness he does not disappoint as decent, career-minded homicide detective Thomas Craven.
With handsome Greg Wise playing a former colleague of dubious intent, the plot thickens to an interesting twist without scaring the bejeebers out of you.
It isn't as rich in content as Ratatouille but, with Liam Neeson voicing a raccoon and lots of kid-specific silliness, it's a nice snack as nuts tend to be.
Just because a film is about dance doesn't mean it can function without a plot and a modicum of decent dialogue. Step Up: All In has neither.

The action sequences, 3D or not, are text-book daring and explosive, but it is the music that raises the bar in this film as, during moments of extreme danger, a Seventies classic comes on to ease the tension.

[It] is all about the family's altruism and turns a blind eye to silent Michael, with father Sean offering up the excuse: "Michael's gift is his ability to forget." I'm not convinced but that didn't stop me from enjoying the film and admiring Bullock.

The nursery rhyme names, lashings of ginger beer and a motorbike and sidecar trip to London ... would have liked it will have the killjoys claiming the film is seasoned to American taste but I found it utterly charming.
Fun and girly are key adjectives in this movie.
A thief trapped in a house with a serial killer who collects and tortures nice families is all the preamble you will need to prepare for the terror that I hid from.
Tetro is an acquired taste.
As a committed Allenphile who once dressed like Annie Hall and longed to be Hannah's sister, I've loved all of Woody's work and his latest is no exception.

Hill is loveable as the good guy forced to do bad things that upset his medical missus, played by Mad Men's Elisabeth Moss, and Australian actress Rose Byrne from Damages is a revelation as Aldous's cockney ex-lover.

It remains a mystery to me how a street-smart, wise-cracking comic of Chris Rock's pedigree failed to see the laughter limitations of this remake of Frank Oz's British film, which was equally uninspiring.
I loved The Brothers Bloom from the moment it started, when we are introduced to two orphaned boys in dark brimmed hats who are con merchants in the making.
I found the novel more interesting than the film, which is a torturous, drawn-out affair.

As talking animal movies go Babe set the benchmark for me and this isn't in the same ball park ... but the small children in the audience were very still suggesting that any animal with something to say deserves their attention. It just didn't hold mine.
If the team behind Piranha is planning a sequel they will need to recast as many of the key players were eaten during the craziest 88 minutes I've ever spent in the cinema.
The plot, which sees the return of communist Russians intent on tearing down American society, makes for a welcome change when cinema and television are obsessed with Muslim bad guys.
Trust me, [there's] a scene you need to witness with a crowd that whoops and cheers, which is really what this film demands of its audience throughout.

Having gone to an all-girls school where fainting got you out of gym, seeing Carol Morley's The Falling about an extreme version of this set in 1969 was weird but compelling, as at this school the prettiest and most audacious pupil dies.
An interesting mélange of dark humour, creepy episodes, Sir Ben Kingsley as the doctor and Kate Beckinsale as the manic eye candy explains why Newgate stays longer than any sane man would.
This deeply-moving, finely executed film is not just a must-see, but a reminder at a time when immigration is a key election issue that party politics can be as misleading as a movie poster.

With delectable James Spader voicing Ultron, a robotic artificial intelligence programme, and an opening sequence with The Avengers battling a terrorist group in a frozen wood, Whedon has more than delivered on his promise.

Directed by Louise Osmond, the film follows the extraordinary and moving experience of a syndicate in an extremely poor Welsh mining village who came to own a thoroughbred that defied their expectations.
On paper it is a yawn, especially when you clock the four-hour running time, but you will be sucked in to the lives of the characters and the mesmerising detail of their existence.
movie_title: Home from Home: Chronicle of a Vision (Die Andere Heimat) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Hopefully the leaders in the Middle East will take a look at this film as I'm sure Pierre could teach them all some new steps.

Having read Neil Gaiman's novella a number of times, I had my own idea of what the little girl who discovers an alternative and terrifying other world in her own home should be like but director Henry Selick's vision knocks spots off my own.

Submerged in her character's physical limitations and mental anguish, Aniston gets it right whether grimacing in pain or recoiling in anger and if Meryl Streep, Hilary Swank or Julia Roberts had played the part, I know they'd be up for an Oscar.
The only thing more tedious than stoned people philosophizing about the existence of God is boys who can't bring themselves to say 'I love you.'
This is nothing less than a cult classic in the making.
movie_title: I Am Not a Serial Killer (2016)

movie_review_blurb: If there is a lesson to be learned from Trainwreck, it's that you can't succeed if you never try. It's one of those platitudes often touted in sports, charmingly and appropriately repurposed here.
The Green Inferno is a movie that you'll likely never feel the need to revisit, though it must be seen to be experienced -- and that experience will linger with you.
For a film about connections, Gilliam makes it too hard for his audience to connect.
Cage returns to the Las Vegas he once famously left, joined by Elijah Wood for a simple but mostly effective heist flick.

Theron is the hero we need right now: As devilishly self-serving and smooth as Bond, as physically dynamic and stoic as Wick, Lorraine is confidently equipped to join the legacy of great movie action heroes and she doesn't need your permission.
Her, at its heart, is a story about being human, and to be human is to be so many beautiful, wonderful things.
As a martial arts action film, Man of Tai Chi is fun enough -- the fights are engaging, Chen's moves are breathtaking, and Keanu Reeves goes full Keanu Reeves.
What We Do in the Shadows totally nails it from beginning to end with not a single tedious or wasted moment.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful, moving, highly emotional piece of drama featuring unquestionably exhausting work from its two female leads.

Slaboshpitsky... has definitely delivered something rare and singular -- the sort of experience we hope to find in cinema, not just because it's new and we haven't seen it, but because it's truly stimulating work.
Hours goes from a passable, decent, (but hardly thrilling) thriller to a film that gives your eye-rolling muscles a total workout.

Excessive in its simplicity, yet simplistic in its excess, 'Grand Piano' is a sharp thriller that knows exactly what it is and what it wants to do -- like any good concert, the goal is to entertain, and it succeeds fairly well.

It's a bit of a mainstream comedy, sure, and for that it sometimes feels slight or conventionally paced, but it's packed with more heart and perception than most, and it treats its characters as fully realized people.
The Invitation is an exceptionally unnerving thriller, a sharp study in the horrors of platonic indulgence and the over-extension of courtesy.
The Neon Demon is as deceptive as shattered glass, with a brilliant beauty so mesmerizing that you don't notice its murderously sharp edges until you're bleeding all over the floor.

Where Frozen was a defiantly chilly breath of fresh air, Moana feels somewhat stagnant. Despite a few fantastic deviations (including the lack of a love interest to hinder our hero's development), Moana is still very much a paint-by-numbers narrative.
A gloriously sensual and impressively layered thriller that's every bit as Hitchcockian and gothic as its predecessor.
Split is [Shyamalan's] most thoughtful film in years, and one that contains ideas and feelings that resonate on a deep, visceral level.

A gloriously real story that feels as timeless as the great teen comedies of John Hughes, and as painful as My So-Called Life. It's the kind of movie that only comes around once every decade or so, but it's well worth the wait.

It's become increasingly rare for horror films to make an effort to truly scare us these days, but Jennifer Kent's 'The Babadook' gets under the skin in ways that are both visceral and highly emotional.

Though it may come off as Malick for hip-hop-loving millennials, Arnold's film is a surprisingly poignant experience, a sprawling yet intimate odyssey through Middle America, and a bracingly honest portrait of emerging adulthood.

Blending the irreverent humor and gory coming-of-age allegory... Raw is a unique and refreshing addition to cinema - and yet another example of France's remarkably artful and existential approach to horror.
A righteous follow-up that's bigger and maybe not better, but just as good as its predecessor.

Featuring a razor sharp performance from the incomparable Isabelle Huppert, Verhoeven's latest effort is an expertly layered drama in which a successful woman experiences a rather unconventional midlife awakening.
With Baby Driver, Edgar Wright is officially five-for-five, a rare accomplishment in filmmaking and one that basically guarantees his elevation to all-timer status.
Small Crimes is a solid follow-up that's more dramatic than its predecessor with the same mean streak.
Simple in both concept and execution, Gemini rewards viewers who aren't anxious to outsmart it, and are more interested in seeing a movie that's, you know, good.

Bill Condon's live-action update of Beauty and the Beast is more reimagining than remake, a lavish and lovely take on a familiar tale (as old as time, no doubt) that enriches its source material without betraying it.
Anton Yelchin's remarkable talent was (and remains) undeniable, but not even he could save Porto.
While there's an abundance of information and stories to be told, Sound City at times becomes almost as idle as its aging idols.
The Spectacular Now works because it insists on allowing these actors and characters to pull you in with their alarming emotional candor.
Veronica Mars will inevitably delight fans of the series to no end, but newbies shouldn't be shy -- it's actually quite the perfect introduction to the series.

Devil's Due is the latest entry in the found footage horror genre, and while it does have its fair amount of creative visual effects, the thrills are hardly thrilling in this paint by numbers occult chiller.
Blockers finally gives young women the teen sex comedy they deserve
The cinematic equivalent of a pop-culture mashup tee.
Disquieting as hell.
There's definitely a line between decadence and over-indulgence, and where The Last Circus was certainly the former, Witching and Bitching is unfortunately the latter.
An astonishing, subversive take on tired clichés.
A unique perspective wasted on a film that fails to deliver any actual excitement.
As thought-provoking as it is hilarious.
This gorgeous genre film from Norway, with its themes of suppressed sexuality, will undoubtedly resonate with members of LGBTQ communities around the world.
One of the most disturbing cinematic experiences of the year.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Really good. Scary good, even.
For those who acutely empathize with the ravages of grief, Shults has delivered a film more horrific than any boogeyman or ghoul in recent memory.
Black Mirror for Dummies.
Win It All is a largely enjoyable exercise in the concept of acting as reacting, as most of the film's plot (and humor) is driven by the ways people respond to Eddie and his predicament.

Nothing Bad Can Happen is one of the smartest, most heartbreaking films of the year. Gebbe has meticulously crafted a film that knows exactly what it is, what it needs to say, and what it wants from its audience.
... Gerald's Game isn't exclusively a story about trauma, but one of survival.
Unfortunately, Fuqua's film is tonally discordant, vacillating between gloriously ridiculous and mind-numbing; sometimes it's just plain dull.

In a World... is far from perfect and doesn't quite have the laser-focus of a more seasoned writer and director, but even the most awkward and fumbling moments of the film are a joy to watch and experience.
Jarmusch brings his arthouse sensibilities to the vampire genre, removing the focus from needless stereotypes and finding the humanity in the inhuman.
A movie that explores the full spectrum of relationships with impeccable wit, delightfully dark humor and insights so sharp they verge on deadly.
Vigalondo is a talented filmmaker, but this thriller is perhaps a little too ambitious with an execution that doesn't convey all of his big ideas in a way that's cohesive and consistent.
West also proves that horror can draw from real-world scenarios and give us surprisingly profound moments.
It may be Wheatley's least accessible film to date - and also his best.

A brilliant, uncompromising and deliberate experiment set in a very specific time, in a very specific place, and under incredibly specific conditions, A Field in England is a wonderfully bizarre microcosm of abstraction.

While Blue Jasmine is first and foremost a character study and a showcase for Blanchett's impeccable acting skills, it's also a meditation on the idea of what we deserve versus what we think we deserve, and the intersection of standards and entitlement.
Optimistically speaking, Carrie could have been worse. But the depressing truth is that it could have been so much better.
A film that thinks it's way smarter than it is, and in doing so, sets itself up for failure by creating an expectation it can't possibly satisfy, insulting your intelligence in the process.
While it doesn't always stick the landing and the plot threads feel a little clumsily tied, The Way, Way Back succeeds where it counts with its big, sloppy heart.
Absurd stretches in logic aside, for a film about salesmanship, The Internship does a horrible job of selling itself as a funny (or real) movie.

Miss Peregrine's could have been a thoughtful and bold metatextual thesis on Burton's entire career. Instead, like its partially-formed villainous apparitions, it comes frustratingly close to achieving substance.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: As a film, Let's Be Cops glides in the same way its characters do. Though it charms, it's difficult to ignore how many times we've seen this story played out before.
It doesn't re-invent the vine, but The Legend of Tarzan swings its way into being one of the better on-screen adaptations of the classic character.
Marvel is getting increasingly good at delivering great movies based on material that shouldn't really work on film.
It may not be the next Hunger Games-esque blockbuster franchise, but it's an enjoyable ride through time and peculiarity.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: More often than not it's a charming, Eastern-influenced myth that's beautiful to watch and enjoyable to follow.
Kingsglaive won't set the world on fire, but it might just be the best movie that bears the Final Fantasy name. That's not a high bar, but it's an accomplishment.
It was supposed to show us that the folks at Warner Bros. still know how to make great comic book movies. Suicide Squad is not very successful at that.
It's no flawless classic, but it's an exciting and often funny ride through a neighborhood where something strange is going on.
The animation is wonderful, leading to plenty of colorful visual gags and over-the-top situations.
Little more than a dumb action blockbuster that has a bit of style but little substance.

By the time it ends, Arrival is a story that could only be told in the science-fiction genre, and the result is a beautiful narrative that you find has been telling you things about itself without you ever realizing it.
A few jokes try to be clever (for example, there's a Wilhelm Scream joke that your kids aren't going to appreciate), but more often than not they keep it simple -- and sometimes stupid.
It strikes a near perfect balance between fun family comedy and message film, never feeling like it's too much of either.
Calling Deadpool "just another comic book movie" would do injustice to a film that makes a strong effort to deliver something different.
Fun, funny, gory and yet still strangely romantic.
Even when I was laughing, even when well-written lines were well-delivered, it was hard to shake the feeling that I'd seen it all before.
Goosebumps is chock full of fun moments whether they're all logical or not, and it's an adventure that should appeal to both young viewers new the series and older readers who devoured them as kids.
What it lacks in character development ... Pan overcompensates for in style.
Sure, it's a movie aimed at teenagers in which an unpopular guy wants to get a popular girl, but there's a lot more to this story's map between points A and B.
The experience is an exercise in cringing at bad one-liners and stomaching dumb plot devices before saying, "Aww, look, Q-Bert!"
The plot does little other than serve as a vehicle for the eye candy of colorful characters and wondrous landscapes.
Moana makes for a great role model for young children, especially girls.
The Last Jedi is funny, it's emotional, it's fast-paced and it has a good story to tell.
Assassin's Creed is good evidence that sometimes a video game is the better medium than a movie with which to tell a story.
It's visually splendid, packed with imagination and offers powerful messages about love, individuality and self-acceptance.
The story is interesting and the beats are well-acted, but it's the musical numbers that make The Greatest Showman.
It's a whimsical, touching and heartfelt celebration of Mexican traditions and folklore, and it's one of the more original stories the acclaimed animation studio has told in years.
I went into Justice League with high hopes but low expectations. It exceeded the expectations, but didn't rise to the level of the hopes.
Murder on the Orient Express isn't particularly mind-blowing, but it serves as good crime story comfort food -- a whodunit that's easy to settle in with for a couple of hours.
The third film about Marvel's superhero based on the Norse god of thunder shakes things up drastically, taking the series in a more colorful, more fantastic and more comedic direction.
While Blade Runner 2049 may not end up being the classic the original is, in some ways it's as good of a sequel as you could ask for.
Valerian is sci-fi at its most fantastical. It's a shame that the dialogue, acting and anything involving humans too often feels stilted and unbelievable.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The costumed antics of Homecoming are a joy to watch, with tense set pieces and well-choreographed action, but some of the movie's brightest spots are in its more down-to-earth moments.

Yes, it's part of a series that is now eight movies strong, but it also works alone as a movie about war, oppression, a dangerous heist, a daring rebellion and a spark of hope that ignites the final stages of a revolution.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The dead tell a tale in the latest Pirates of the Caribbean movie, but unfortunately that tale is erratic, filled with holes, peppered with far-too-convenient plot points and tarnished by over-the-top situations ...
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's got some interesting ideas packed inside cool cinematography and high-octane action, but those things come at the expense of plot and character development, making it a fairly typical summer popcorn movie.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Vol. 2 doesn't take long to get moving, and once it starts, it just goes. There isn't a lot in the way of downtime and there aren't any moments of filler.
The plot and character developments never reach Marvel-levels of script writing, but they're above average for the B- or C-tier stuff you might expect from this movie.
It runs long and has a bit more action than it really needs, but Logan will likely find a spot among the best comic book adaptations to grace a movie theater.
Lego Batman is a clear high point for modern movies based on DC Comics, and the rest of Warner Bros.' superhero slate should learn from it.
MacDougall skillfully rises to the challenge of portraying this struggle, carrying the emotional weight that the story demands, and displaying a solid range between deep sadness and intense anger.
Disappointing at best, problematic at worst.
Taken just at face value as a superhero movie, Wonder Woman is one of the best in its class, matching some of the better efforts in a genre that Marvel has dominated for years.
It deviates from everything it's structured the franchise to be, but it's also a perfect example of taking big risks for even bigger wins.
Despite the terrifying and gruesome subject matter, Beware the Slenderman is a documentary that fails to spook or even chill.

It may approach the subject of religious fundamentalism in a somewhat passionless manner, but Timbuktu is still a thought-provoking, highly topical tale that surprisingly seeks to entertain as it educates.
With Exhibition, Joanna Hogg advances her impressive directing style with a visually striking - if decidedly chilly - look at a couple reaching stalemate in their stifling London home.
Frustratingly over-egged, Alex Gibney's Finding Fela! attempts to take on too much, then adds more. Thankfully, though, the music and the man make it worth a glance.
There's an effective love story at Testament of Youth's core, but the misery of this nuance-free adaptation of Vera Brittain's autobiography drowns the romance in tedium.
The New York Review Of Books: A 50 Year Argument Review is a substantial and surprisingly accessible browse through half a century of The New York Review of Books. If only there were more of it.
movie_title: The New York Review of Books: A 50 Year Argument (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It could use a touch more balance, but The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz is a passionate, angry piece of factual filmmaking about the fate of revolutionary thinking in the modern world.
movie_title: The Internet's Own Boy: The Story of Aaron Swartz (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cold, alienating and only occasionally gripping, Heli is an uneasy mix of black comedy, social realist drama and crime thriller. If only the rest of the film matched the slickly confident cinematography.
A lot of the film rather becomes about the will they/won't they romance between Davidson and Smolan, reducing an epic journey to something less than it should be.
A quiet, contemplative drama about the war after war.
A valuable introduction to these two filmmakers' work for budding film enthusiasts.
Socially, politically and emotionally switched-on, Diego Star is another one to add to your growing list of Quebecois films you want to see.
Fight Club may be iconic and technically proficient, but it's more distant than perhaps any film to attain "modern classic" status.
Populated by bland characters and saturated with tedious dialogue.
Howard's good sense on Rush is to repeat his Frost/Nixon success by surrounding himself with superior writing and acting talent
A great performance surrounded by a very bad movie.

The artificial dialogue clashes with the austere realism of director Justin Kurzel's approach, but Macbeth should be seen for its striking horror style and Michael Fassbender's mentally-scarred take on the title character.
Locke trusts the main performance unquestionably and...gives Tom Hardy the best showcase yet for his ferocious magnetism.
It's a set of events that might seem more acceptable in TV comedy drama, but on the big screen they're just glaringly unlikely.
Filth is filthy fun.
Past dissecting Hardy the public image, as a biography of two real-life subjects, Legend is less satisfying.
Really Free Fire's a movie about its own craft and the interplay between its actors-not to mention a trial run at bigger budgeted and more "mainstream" filmmaking for Wheatley.
Overlong and bloated, Spectre is a few rewrites away from greatness. Still, there's no denying that it's an eccentric epic and undeniably fun, despite a languorous final stretch.

Khondji's cinematography doesn't just complement Gray's movie, it deepens its meaning, strengthening the appeal of Fawcett's jungle, endlessly verdant and mysterious where home in England appears dull and monotone.

My Scientology Movie isn't particularly deep-Alex Gibney's Going Clear comfortably remains the definitive film on this subject-but Theroux tackles what you might already know in a wryly compelling way.
Scott clearly isn't trying to make a definitive statement on the consequences of global warming -- instead he appears determined to encourage a new line of thinking.

If you want reality -- if you want an idea, for one, as to how the British people could become so despairing that they would do something as drastic as vote to leave the European Union -- see I, Daniel Blake.
It's a turn of minor gestures that lacks the obvious Best Actor grandstanding to, say, win an Oscar, but rest assured Driver's performance is one of the most impressive given this year.

Anyone who's ever wondered how Michael Shannon would fare as a smoldering romantic lead or how Imogen Poots might handle the role of a femme fatale has their answer in Matthew Ross' engaging psycho-thriller.
Even by Nicolas Cage's now shockingly low standards, Arsenal is bad.
Lady Macbeth begins as a biting tale of female empowerment but slowly reveals itself to be something much crueler. Period pieces rarely feel this contemporary.
Gorgeously empty, The Duelist is more interesting as a reflection of the Russian sociopolitical climate today than it is as an actual goddamn movie.
The Last Man on the Moon is not just a tribute to one man, though -- it's also an elegy for a time when humankind still appeared determined to achieve impossible goals.
movie_title: The Last Man On The Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The strange, bright scuzziness of the overall style elevates Triple 9's more familiar elements, such as the Heat-like heists and the tense cop vs. crook stand-offs.

When disappointments rack up, there comes a point where fans have to question whether the "comic genius" is really worthy of the label-and for Sacha Baron Cohen, The Brothers Grimsby will be that moment to take stock.
If it were a regular R-rated comedy, Deadpool's "taboo" ingredients wouldn't be considered boundary-breaking at all. But in a superhero movie, this stuff feels revolutionary.

Under the Shadow features two major breakouts: [star] Narges Rashidi... and [director Babak] Anvari, who with his debut proves himself as adept at politically-charged social-realism as he is at horror.
Male anger and resentment drive this savage tale, a thriller as gripping as it is stomach-churningly frank.

Already seriously in the running to take the prize for Worst Movie of 2016, Warcraft may prove that the fabled video game adaption "curse" is so strong that it can bring even the most talented of young filmmakers to their knees.
It's a moving story. And the fact that [Aronofsky's] done his biblical homework makes it that much more so.

The story of the sniper attack, which left 16 dead and three dozen wounded, is told in an extremely compelling style that combines interviews, actual film footage and animated recreations. I highly recommend this one.
"The Witness" is fascinating enough for its careful reporting of the circumstances surrounding the infamous murder, but equally as a study of the impact of crimes on those left behind.
Edelman allows us to truly understand O.J. Simpson, maybe for the first time; how he was built, what he is made of. It also tells us a great deal about ourselves.
There's always something a bit haunting in seeing a person so funny and smart and vibrant on film, knowing they would soon be gone.
At two-and-a-half hours, the film features Wayne and Kent mostly glowering at each other at swanky high-rise parties as the rabble teems below.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: . . .each of the movie's potential highs loses direction and intensity too soon to establish any foundation of empathy from the audience toward her, likable or not.
"Hello, My Name Is Doris" is a story about not wanting to be forgotten, or even deemed unessential. It stars Sally Field at her most Sally Field: gently neurotic, goofy, adorable and heartbreaking.
The posturing, the costume, the mournful wail is there, but there is a distance between the character and the life story of Williams that never fully reaches below the poised surface.
Though this movie is about Gods of Egypt, most are hardly seen past the first 10 minutes or they are so thinly written that it's amazing they weren't consumed by their own character holes. . .

"10 Cloverfield Lane" manages to accomplish the rare feat of. . .still retaining the bare-bones structure, simplicity of thrills and chills that made its predecessor such an effective surprise eight years ago.
From the first scene of "Zootopia," Disney's latest animated film, the moral is made clear: to moralize is good, but to bust one's chops is better.
Fortunately for the story, Clavius's internal struggle and the investigation itself are intense enough to compensate for the dearth of cultural thoughtfulness.

Jon Favreau's adaptation of the 1967 film "The Jungle Book" melds live action with eye-popping CGI and makes an old story fresh again with a refusal to pander to its audience, regardless of age (but especially the younger viewers).

Be prepared for a level of vulgarity that hugs the film like a warm blanket, firmly rooting it in a state of suspended adolescence in which it dares you to find something endearing in our antiheroine, and often succeeds.
"Keanu," about two cousins searching for a stolen kitten, flows like a 1980s buddy comedy with frequent references to Keegan-Michael Key's and Jordan Peele's sketch comedy show.
. . . the magic of childhood glimmers through a film whose director remembers what it was like to be little and use emotions as armor when scary or bad things happen.

The Radners are back and their neighbors are still awful in "Neighbors 2: Sorority Rising," a sequel to the 2014 film that continues to show Greek life in all its self-important, cartoonish debauchery.
. . .the ending is coated with such a layer of sugar that it removes us once again from true empathy for both characters.
"Finding Dory" is about the self-preservation and gumption of a character with special needs throughout her life.
[Director Roland] Emmerich gave us bigger explosions and battles, but the two-hour running time sags under the bloat of thin characters and huge plot holes.
Most of this film feels at war with itself, fighting the Sensitive Man trope with a hearty mix of vulgarity and a myopic sense of what women really want.
. . .pretty intense for a children's film at the height of summer.

I really hope for a sequel, one that can break free of the original (which will remain glorious and magical forever in its own right) and give these women a chance to speak and stretch and breathe on their own.

The female culture caricatured by writer-directors Jon Lucas and Scott Moore is one of compartmentalization. . . The female characters are rarely referred to by any other distinction, as if having children superseded any other identifying trait.
A ragtag assortment of ethnicities, genders and crossbreeds, "Suicide Squad" is not an ode to violence but to the ordered perception we create to rationalize our lust for it, onscreen or otherwise.

Throughout the film that jolts the audience through starts and stops like a crazed bumper-car ride on acid, the promise and glimmers of genius are interspersed between the same old tropes the film attempts to subvert.
. . . What Eastwood, Hanks, and company show is the humanity beneath the spectacle.
"Captain America: Civil War" is a movie about faith - in each other, in leaders, in an ethos - in a universe that is becoming increasingly secular.
At its best parts, the story delights in its self-depiction, even when describing the froth atop a garbage can.
We have a film that has done the unthinkable: made a gazillion dollars despite a convincing argument that it puts full blame on its own audience for what it has become.

"The Boy" is less about a life-size porcelain doll and more about the objectification of a vulnerable young woman by literally everyone around her. And the film is creepier and darker than you would expect in that regard.

This is a film about agency - embracing it or denying someone of their own - and both the consequences of the choices we actively make as well as the evolving rationalizations we create to live with ourselves.
It's refreshing to watch a science-fiction story that remains brilliantly cerebral, demanding the focus of its audience, yet constantly throws us a naughty wink.

We never doubt the direction of the plot because it remains consistent despite the hysterics behind the kitchen doors, thus consigning what could have been a great film to the realm of a competent one.

movie_review_blurb: A tale of forbidden love, customs, rising nationalism and epic tragedy - exuding Merchant Ivory quality in every frame.
One of the summer's nicest surprises..a mostly family-friendly adventure that doesn't rely on superheroes or science fiction to get your pulse racing...
The very Tom Cruise-like Sean Faris makes this respectable portrayal noteworthy considering the gritty sport's irrelevancy to most Americans.
Tropic Thunder stops just short of going over the top with satirical humor that bites with a freshly acute sense of its own relevancy.
If you don't think someone can appreciate this first of many installments unless they have read the books, let it be said one time: Bite me.
Because the much more serious tone was so different than previous installments of Ian Fleming's legendary series, Daniel Craig's debut felt refreshingly updated despite the film's flaws.
Regardless of whether Disney's G-rated phenomenon is your cup of tea, you have to admire this films boundless will to create fun, inspiring entertainment on a level second to none.
Appaloosa is ideally suited for fans of the genre for whom quiet drama speaks as loud as big guns.
The gags come fast and furiously with one-liners to make the case that liberals don't have exclusive rights to humor in Hollywood.
The film relies on rapid-fire gags that will amuse most adults, and cute antics that will satisfy the little ones.
The film is compelling despite a lack of dramatic focus, but Jolie doesn't add a single element to make the film appreciably better.
This sharply written film grows on you with every frame.

The cast is not the problem. They are are merely pawns in this cluttered, Ritalin-infused action film that stretches plausibility so often that it would be more accurately described as science fiction.
Irreverence and cynicism may be the dominant themes of the day, but surely there's a place for a film with the timeless virtues of The Secret Life of Bees.
Neil Labute's examination of the dark fringes of human emotion make Samuel L. Jackson's bulging glare and looming stature unnerving, yet believably sympathetic.
Awkward and sometimes overly subtle, but compelling performances by a cast of normally supporting actors who make the most of their much deserved chance to carry a film.
The film isn't overtly heavy-handed in its violence, but it doesn't provoke enough surprises to keep the mind from drifting -- a poison pill for an action film.
The fact is the talented ensemble cast overshadows the bland, blackmail comedy noir, even though the film's trailer promises quirky fun.
Woody Allen's latest may not convert new fans, but for those interested this lusty travelogue makes the most of its Spanish setting, with fascinating characters.
Wilson has neither the acting chops nor musician's soul to be believable, merely a rip-off of Jack Black and Will Ferrell.
Faris's Marilyn Monroe-inspired breathy delivery feels forced and gets old fast. Only the scene-stealing Emma Stone shows any promise.
Traitor is filled with more surprises and originality than last year's much ballyhooed Michael Clayton and Don Cheadle deserves much of the credit.
It's unclear which is worse -- to so liberally steal from films like Children of Men and Minority Report, or to be so offensively dumb in the process.
What this video scrapbook lacks in storytelling it makes up for in earnestness and a willingness to show the trials as well as the quiet triumphs of missionary life.
Leatherheads really doesn't know what kind of film it is, and as a result it shanks the winning kick -not by a mile- but by enough to be a disappointment.
Welcomed doses of slapstick and winking humor are sprinkled throughout rescuing the film from the occasionally heavy but never overbearing exposition.
Those who like their comedy, romance, and tragedy in quiet doses should enjoy this textured story.
While not a classic in its own right, The Bucket List displays two great actors in classic form, a sort of Planes, Trains and Automobiles for maturing audiences.
Bursting with star power, comes off as a smart comedy, economically written and briskly paced while making politics more fun than they have a right to be.
And one more bonus, the technology almost convinces us Angelina Jolie can act. Revolutionary, indeed.
Weird on paper, strangely and sweetly affecting onscreen. See it. You won't regret it.
A film so filled with clichés of the genre and plot points so dumb that even a novice would end up laughing.
A quietly moving story about a single Father and his Son. This decent film gets better as you watch it.
Parents longing for entertaining and intelligent family superhero fare would be much better served renting 2005's Zathura or Sky High.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Better to fold 'em than to spend time watching Eric Bana and Drew Barrymore go literally nowhere.
If you can stomach it, expect to leave the theater shaken yet entertained by every jolting, unexpected minute.
While no rational person would believe Castro and Hillary are to be exalted, its medical horror stories are absolutely believable by anyone who's dealt with an HMO.
A richly rewarding film experience that rises to the top of its genre.
An overachiever of a film that practically defines the term summer blockbuster.
It's unlikely many fans will have the patience to sit through this soulless, yet visually enticing voyage to nowhere more than once.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Solid, if somewhat derivative filmmaking. A quiet thriller with some great performances.
The kind of film your parents will cite as the reason they don't go to movies anymore.
Feels refreshed and might be -- especially for relieved parents -- the most entertaining film of the franchise.
While it in no critical area improves upon the magic of its deliriously watchable original installment, it's flashier and funnier than expected.
Boyle's skilled direction along with Anthony Dod Mantle's cinematography thrusts the viewer into a world that is completely foreign to an American audience but earns its affection nonetheless.
Each film would have fared better as a 15-minute short.
A diligent ensemble can't lift the film to anything higher than a shallow fairy tale with only worthy intentions.
Friendship, loyalty, tragedy, and politics are themes sensitively and sometimes terrifyingly examined. But the film's hopeful spirit hits home despite the differences in our culture and language.
Katherine Heigl impresses and James Marsden is predictably dreamy in this always a bridesmaid never a you-know-what, been there, done that cliché-ridden formulaic rom-com.
It may take a rocket scientist to successfully count cards, but not to wite a smarter script than what 21 delivers.
Seen through the eyes of a child, this adaptation my lack originality but is fast paced, contains enough fantasy to balance the family drama and is, at times, very scary.
Who will our unlucky in love protagonist ultimately choose? Even if one correctly surmises, the journey is filled with quietly humorous and engaging moments.
Similar to a theme park ride that scares kids, this Asian horror film frightens only newcomers to the genre from which it practically bootlegs.
This Spanish psychological mystery is captivating, creepy and hopeful.
The whodunit-with-terrorist-undertones doesn't test, shock or surprise the audience in any unique way.
Earns plenty of laughs without sinking to gross-out levels.
Downey charms the heck out of the opportunity he's given.

Burton and Depp again prove to be a marvelous combination in this gory yet glorious adaptation of the Stephen Sondheim musical. When was the last time you winced and became misty-eyed in the same movie?
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Poehler's the engine that propels this light comedy to surprising levels that far exceed the predictability suggested by the preview trailer.
Its eye candy may not satisfy anyone other than the most dedicated of fans. This film could have used a heavy dose of Spielberg pacing and Pixar personality.
Lingers long after the lights come up. We can be grateful that films of quiet, unique beauty continue to be made.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: An inane script buries good actors who have terrific chemistry... A convoluted treasure hunt plot and sinking sentimentality don't help.

The lack of irony or humor -- except for the occasional unintended chuckles provoked by certain platitudinal one-liners -- here separates the violence from Tarantino films or graphic novel adaptations that often use their bloodfests to parody or to bemuse
Different in all the right ways-- a complex, unpredictable attempt at giving its audience a lot to chew on. Pardon those of us who will take a flawed opus over bloated unoriginality.
For better or for worse, it's Burton's imagination that keeps the proceedings lively, even if its' not as blatantly humorous as we'd like.
[A] spotty, but ultimately effective thriller.
With the help of a great screenplay and tremendous acting, this film ... soars above the typical minority/underdog formula to inspire more than it manipulates.
The character development and spiritual themes present in the first film are downplayed allowing room to showcase its grand scale production values at the cost of some heart.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: While effective in spots, the abrupt, powerful ending would have worked better as a short story.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The year's sharpest film--but it may not speak to everyone.
The uninspired screenplay and all too obvious cast of novices make the film feel more like charity work on the part of its engaging director and star.
This box needed a STOP button.
As breathtaking as it is heartbreaking.
Its' lavish details bridge the gap between the real and the imagined in a way heretofore impossible.. the filmmakers have put most of their magic in the media and not the message.
A suitably suspenseful homemade haunted house creep show made on a low budget that is also a patience tester in need of a fast forward button.
Plenty of good elements here, but a lack of cohesion and a lackluster performance by the lead actor make the film at best a decent rental.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Despite the focus on young, shirtless werewolves and well coiffed vampires, the second installment of Stephanie Meyer's immensely popular series comes off as a tepid adventure in Zombieland.
Instead of being a sharp, witty comedy about married couples experiencing vacation therapy together, it's more of a pinheads-in-paradise routine with only a few funny lines.
A wickedly witty, post-apocalyptic zombie kill-fest that is actually smarter than it is gory, which, of course, it is.
A visual flair can't rescue an awkardly edited, talky film with little accessible wit--hard to imagine even the most patient child or their parents not being bored stiff.
What we have here is a challenging, psychological rendering of a child's classic that may indeed be too unexciting and melancholy for kids, and too unstructured to be fully appreciated by adults.
Despite its somewhat contrived formula, Whip It feels like a spirited Indie that refuses to sell out, demonstrating respect for both its characters and its audience.
Its humanity, some cool technology and Bruce Willis save this film from simply being a compilation of a zillion similarly themed "too much technology" lessons.
Matt Damon is delightfully goofy as an agri-business whistleblower, but the mostly true story lacks the drama or wit to keep us more than just amused.
Love Happens is more about catharsis than chemistry. It's not a terrible film, but like skydiving lessons, you'd better know what you're getting into beforehand.
Its lack of melodrama and shock value make it all the more refreshing. Consider this film a grittier, inner city cousin of HSM and that's no back handed compliment
By letting his brilliant dialogue-centered screenplay showcase his superb cast and keeping the gory violence in check, this fictional WWII saga is Tarantino's masterpiece. Who knew?
A hardcore depiction of modern war and the brave soldiers who fight, while quietly but assuredly begging the question: War, what is it good for?
Original in concept and thoroughly intense, this alien encampment sci-fi thriller quickly devolves into a gritty slaughter chase that never bores but rarely surprises.
Ricky Gervais stars and directs and takes a good premise and some funny bits and tries to get philosophical, only to come up short in both laughs and depth.
Charming yet brutally honest..offers a certain mainstream appeal for anyone who's experienced love's thorny and persuasive illusions.
Your stage in life will likely determine your ability to see the truth and subtle power in this gentle and worthwhile film though its certainly not a seasonal spirit lifter.
Though old school in craft, Disney proves that a good story infused with terrific music and lovable characters can still be a winning formula.
Familiar territory, movingly if not memorably explored.
A decent action film that tackles interesting subject material that deserves attention but many won't pay to see oversimplified finger-pointing even if it features some of our favorite actors.
A star turn by Carey Mulligan playing a 16-year-old who gets charmed (and, uh, educated) by a suspiciously alluring older man, the excellent Peter Sarsgaard.
An enticing, engaging piece of work, worthy of a second viewing, which is never a bad thing.
The simple story of a Merle Haggard-type has been who falls in love with a younger reporter is aided greatly by excellent songs and dazzling performances by Jeff Bridges and Colin Farrell.
A trippy, uneven ride whose best assets are its imagination, Heath Ledger's final performance, and the three surprise stars who act as his replacements.
Proves that old-fashioned stories are fashionable again; only romantics not cynics, need apply.
Even with its flaws, it's a top-notch nail biter that tries to be less about the kills and more about the thrills.
Rebirths the old fashioned action epic in a era of soulless marketing machines, desensitizing shock pieces, and overrated indie-art imposters. Cameron's vision exceeds the hype.
A silly, preposterous romantic comedy that benefits from Josh Duhamel's self-assured likeability, which helps a thin script that relies on pratfalls not brain power.
No doubt the filmmaker's intentions were to serve up a tasty sampler platter while understanding that the cinematic equivalent of candy hearts could never make for a fully satisfying main course
Benecio Del Toro is suitably brooding in this well-intentioned, credibly gothic and gory update that still feels only half right.
Streep and Baldwin sell it.
We need more rom-coms for Moms and their daughters but despite Adams' charms this film has zero sizzle.
Swashbuckling smarts and Downey, Jr. as the perfect super-sleuth.
The sum of the parts of this film while tantalizing and worth a watch, leave the viewer, like its lead character, lacking closure.
Plausible plot points, great special effects and characters we care about. That's really about all you need to enjoy this Apocalypse Wow!
A solid but flawed film--Freeman's charmingly disarming portrayal keeps it real.
This story has merit, so it's a shame it isn't a stronger adaptation of the true events that inspired it.
What it lacks in originality and creativity it makes up for with action and a talented cast that breathes life into its thinly drawn characters.
This kind of film should teach you something about the art of cooking and make you hungry. It does both and the results, while not overpowering are sweet and succulent.
A more mean spirited but still very funny film aimed mainly at Woody'searly period devotees that includes a spirited turn by Evan Rachel Wood.
It won't receive the critical ballyhoo of his previous film, but where Gilroy's 'Michael Clayton' lacked imagination and surprise, 'Duplicity' is a fun, witty romp.
No mojo in its dojo.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Isla Fisher has appeal to spare, but this graceless, witless, unfunny so-called "comedy" does little more than reinforce the worst female stereotypes.

Clever one-liners and a screenplay that doesn't try too hard to be poignant or contrived make for an easy-going film that will lead to interesting post-movie discussion.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Neeson is a major reason Taken, a riveting, revenge thriller gets praiseworthy marks.

It pulls the heartstrings 20 minutes longer than it should-- after it runs out of story--but it's a much needed feel-good film.
This long and somber journey is nonetheless fascinating to watch thanks to the technology behind Brad Pitt's aging from old to young and visuals that contain a lasting power.
movie_title: The Curious Case of Benjamin Button (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If Bride Wars is any indication of what's to come, please let last year linger a little longer.

Chris Columbus has fallen off the edge of the earth. His latest film is a misguided ship sailing among an increasingly rocky body of work.

This sixth installment is likeably unremarkable and feels like some sort of Diagon Alley deja-vu; a road, an overly long road, we've been down many times.

A must see, in whatever format.

With its moving exploration of billowy battles and the men that fight them it's an epic film that looks every inch the spectacle it aims to be.

movie_review_blurb: "Big Fat Greek Wedding's" huge success was a surprise to me and to Hollywood. It won't have the mass appeal and will make only a fraction of the dough-but this film I get.

We get the comedy we settle for.

movie_review_blurb: A scarier and better Harry, but the big secret in this chamber is how the film avoided the PG-13 rating it undoubtedly deserved.

the film, like its central character, is resolute in its objective. Perhaps too resolute.

Not as well executed as Taken or with the depth of 1988's Frantic but Neeson can cover up a lot of plot problems. A good rental.
Script-wise, there is nothing truly revelatory here, but the patient viewer will be rewarded by a film of unique awe and heart wrenching wonder.
Wears its valor and vigor on its sleeve daring to be old-fashioned in its depiction of American heroism. The spirit of "Semper Fi" hasn't been this much fun in a long time.
A fun romp in this cautionary tale that glides by relying heavily on star Bradley Cooper's charisma.
A serviceable, if brutal assassin action pic whose formula flaws are easy to overlook with Jason Statham and Ben Foster involved.
Can't be defined by its 'R' rating or by the 'period piece' label. It may be about a king, but it speaks to the royalty in all of us.
Good direction and a decent cast help the shaky casting of Channing Tatum in this poor man's "Gladiator" that offers some twists and terrific scenery. Worth a rental.
Offers several surprises to balance out the predictable moments, and a natural warmth not usually found in anything with Sandler's name on it.
Mixes the melodrama of Twilight with the hokey horror of The Village but falls short of being 'so bad its good.' It's just not good.
As interesting as its title.
Surely this balancing act involving both heartbreak and humor will polarize those who would prefer that the film stick to one or the other.
Strong in intent but wobbles under the lights.
Unconventional rom-com that is really neither but gets by on the charisma of the cast including Whiterspoon and especially Rudd who can do no wrong.
Takes on a whole different level of realism with Bale, pathetically gaunt yet heroically charismatic, nailing Dicky's double edged nature.
Stands on its' own as an instant classic to which even 'The Duke' himself would tip his hat.
As shallow as the Venetian scenery is beautiful with a preening Jolie and a lackluster Depp stuck in what appears to be a painstakingly long travel commercial.
Best enjoyed in its full 3:D treatment grandeur and without the cynical gaze of old age.
Mulligan is brilliant again but this chilly, sci-fi love story gets mired in tedium and frustrates with lots of unanswered questions-probably by design.
The problem is that we know the 'friends with benefits' deal always leaves someone hurt; the joy would be in seeing how all this lust could believably turn into love.
Minimalist filmmaking makes this a real patience tester.
Part celebration of the spaghetti western with a stunning resolutely 2:D visual style, is geared primarily for adults and is quirky in all the right ways.
If you can buy into the sci-fi angle, this rom-action is smart and brisk enough to stand above similarly-themed films--helped tremendously by the chemistry of its stars.
So light and breezy you might not recognize this Paris postcard comes by way of the ever-relevant Woody Allen, who mixes time travel and nostalgia to delightful effect...
While the film won't likely convert the masses at large (and really doesn't aim to) it has the power to promote the faith of many a believer.
Stellar animation aside, themes such as adoption anxiety, genocide and WMD dominate the storyline-not the usual kiddie fare to be sure.
An unsteady plot and mostly juvenile humor take over for much of the film's 137 minutes, which though blessedly shorter than installments two and three still feels a little long.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A compelling, authentic eye-popping tale with a worthy and ready cast that forces any of the film's flaws to the back burner.
There's something to be respected about a film that doesn't spend most of its time in mindless action
Doesn't belabor its punch lines and it maximizes James' likeability to a mostly winning result.
A somber yet fiery adaptation of the classic Charlotte Bronte novel with sterling performances by leads Mia Wasikowska ('Alice in Wonderland') and Michael Fassbender.
Sprinkled with just enough humor to keep from getting too self-serious, it's briskly paced and gives McConaughey's fans something to brag about... Again.
Nicely combines visual splendor and an earthly fish-out-of-water tale with director Kenneth Branagh bringing a Shakespearean flair to the proceedings.
Funky, random and well shot, this action film about a girl (excellent Saoirse Ronan) trained to be an assassin gets a little overly-stylized and illogical for its own good.
Like Bethany's sunshine filled life, once a great white takes the talented girl's left arm, the film takes a dramatic turn in both tone and artistic execution.
A mostly silent theater filled with kids is one indication of this failed venture, a clock-watching pace and overall lack of creativity are two more
Travels back in time and borrows liberally from the vaults of Rod Serling, and does justice to his legacy.
For those needing preposterous stunts, laugh-out-loud bad dialogue, testosterone-fueled posturing and an "Ocean's 11"-like plot apparently written by and for 13-year-old boys.
There is something inherently noble about making a movie that gets the audience to think a little deeper. A dose of clarity and a pinch of fun never hurt either.
Sadistic and shallow, exploitative and misogynistic, these are the descriptions that 'Sucker Punch' seems not to be so much offended by as revel in.
Makes a case as a worthy adaptation of a good novel but the jury is still out on whether Mr. Pattinson can be more than a brooding vampire.
Even if the story lacks the depth or originality of some of the recent crop of superlative animated films, 'Rio' has an innocent charm to it -- and an explosion of color.
Topically vital, oddly cast, very one-sided political thriller. No real surprises, but engaging.
Boyle's meddling occasionally distracts, but there is no denying the intensity and especially James Franco's skill at recreating climber Aron Ralston's ordeal.
There is high craft here, especially Portman's spellbinding, unsettling performance, but with it comes Aronosfsky's typically off-putting voyeuristic eccentricities.
Enough compelling moments to make one want to grab the book and fill in the blanks that the movie's script seems to have left out.
A sharply written and not overly frantic film that seems to have Looney Tunes in its genes and saves its surprisingly touching moments for just the right times.
Jolie plays a killing machine as well as can be expected, but the chill factor here makes for a joyless, as well as preposterous, journey zapped of any joie de vivre.
A snappy comedy dressed up by its high voltage action sequences--in no small part thanks to the charisma of its' leads.
Even pre-teens will have to endure the fragmented plot lines, stilted acting, and an absence of humor.
More action, more characters, a tad more humor and some interesting backstories help but do nothing to improve upon the series' fatal flaws.
The strong against-type performances of Annette Bening, Naomi Watts, and Samuel Jackson help an absorbing if very uneven script.
A kick-butt family drama with China and Chan as brilliant enhancements.
Nerd Nirvana! Think Napoleon Dynamite on Red Bull. Inventive, quirky, and occasionally very funny.
It's by now a worn out verdict: Another masterpiece by Disney/Pixar.
Precious as all get out...but it cries out for more insight and inspiration.
Scientific credibility issues aside, this creepy sci-fi piece about a lab experiment gone awry is not without merit or surprises, making it flawed but never boring.
Vanessa Redgrave and the spectacular locales of Tuscany are the main reasons to tolerate the tepid and predictable story...
Is it wrong to have higher expectations for a company that is capable of excellence, especially when it is spending upwards of $150 million to make a movie?
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: This is not your Father's Nottingham and that's a good thing.
Fraser's career may be dying hard with this vengeance...
Suffers from a bit of sequel-itis..but don't look for what it isn't; enjoy the solid filmmaking and actors who take their comic book-created roles very seriously.
The timing feels right for the big green guy to pass the torch to the new dragon on the block.
Call us critics jaded, but Killers puts the "kill" in "kill-joy." Try it and see for yourself. Or not.
While the film looks as sharp as a three piece pinstripe from Bloomingdales, featuring some nice character-driven moments, its bubble bursts in an ending that feels compromised.
Not perfect, but its aspirations are admirable, and its execution is surprisingly effective considering (or maybe because of) its unadulterated sentimentality.
A beguiling but only partly satisfying achievement for the "less is more" art house crowd.
Eckhart and Kidman offer two of their finest, most nuanced performances. What could have been suffocatingly gloomy feels authentic and even hopeful.
If you can get past the profanity, this true story of a sister's astonishing effort to free her imprisoned brother is a powerful, Oscar-worthy triumph.
Noted critics have used the words 'unintelligible' and 'impenetrable' to describe the script. Here's a couple more: Boring and meandering.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Carrey and McGregor are fascinating as prison lovers, but the dark tone and explicit sexuality make for a confusing film that also tries to be funny. It rarely succeeds.
While it comes up short in the warmth and depth department, it is notable for a modest comeback of sorts for Harrison Ford.
Adds to the bounty of this year's high quality animated films, and will make the coming awards season jam-packed with difficult choices.
Just what you'd expect and maybe a little more, this no-filler action flick delivers a loud, CGI-free thrill ride with Denzel Washington as an added bonus.
Relies less on graphic violence, more on the menacing mood of its stark fatalism. Just enough humanity to keep the audience engaged and on edge.
We get that the story may not be about answers, but the film could have used a lot more interesting, thought-provoking questions along the way.
Genuinely heartfelt and surprisingly effective in the departments of both laughs and tears, and represents an uptick in the notably declining career of star Katherine Heigl.
What it lacks in originality, this wickedly funny take on a superhero villain makes up for in a multi-layered plot, terrific voicing and well balanced energy.
Call it the film equivalent of the Traveling Wilbury's...a sly caper film that boasts an Oscar laden, all-star veteran cast yet is anything but old and tired.
Let down by a shallow, bland treatment and characters that feign depth and go nowhere. In this category, it is still 'Seabiscuit' by a mile.
An intellectual property battle ripped from today's headlines that feels like a cyber-thriller, yet it never once turns into a heavy-handed message movie.
Has the power to surprise, enrage, and even delight the most cynical of educators and education bashers.
A small scale but modestly effective broken elevator thriller that is more Agatha Christie than Alfred Hitchcock.
Borrows from its' genre without embarassing itself.
A hard-edged thriller with a soft underbelly that continues to solidify Ben Affleck's talents in front of, and behind the camera.
Sex, drugs and F-bombs on the first date...ah, modern romance...
Even contrarians for whom the incredibly popular series has been an uneven road will admit that in this final stop, a team of talented filmmakers have saved their best for last.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Only hints at the comedy and poignancy that its two powerhouse leads could deliver if given better material.
The potty-mouthed script deserves a parental warning and casts the only regretful shadow on an otherwise sterling popcorn adventure...
The action is non-stop and pleasing to the eye, but somewhere along the way, Pixar's soul was left behind.
Isn't sure if it is supposed to be a campy homage, a vampire black comedy, or a family friendly horror pic...doesn't come close to the duo's wondrous collaborations.
Made with precision and verve, this retiree comedy uses veteran actors to bring out the joys and heartbreaks of a life-changing stay in a disheveled Indian hotel.
Appears at first to be a superficial appetizer with little on its mind beyond cliché and predictable formula...but some genuine tenderness surfaces..and Banks is terrific.
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Weinstein was right - 'Bully' should be seen.
If you are inclined to say, 'they had me at Zac Efron' then the hunky actor and his scene-stealing boxer briefs will likely make any logic in this screenplay superfluous.
This sharp, multi-racial adult relationship comedy has enough witty zingers and uses a zesty cast to overcome some structural issues and a too-long running time.
Unflinching as it is unconventional, this gory composite of multiple genres also might be the first thinking man's slasher film.
For fans, the Farrelly bros. take fits the bill. By all means go see it and take an immature friend or a kid at heart.
The main reason to see it (on the big screen, especially) are the delicious, evocative production elements.
Whedon's biggest accomplishment may be making the superhero movie once again super entertainment.
Yes, it is time to return to the chilly North Atlantic to appreciate again James Cameron's glorious epic, for its scope, underappreciated script and perfect casting.
There are exactly seven reasons to tolerate the beautiful artifice on display, but those are-ahem-little reasons, to be sure.
A better story, more humor, and a decent 3D conversion make the swordplay spectacle more tolerable. And hey, 2 Oscar winners play Greek gods!
Loud and long, this 3rd installment boasts a better plot and impressive CGI while maintaining its juvenile level of comedy - the target audience will likely love it.
Raunchy and profane by design, nothing like the 80s TV show, nonetheless hilarious adult comedy - especially the first hour or so.
Nothing here as inspired as the Lightsaber, but there's no Jar Jar Binks either.
Not as satisfying as 'Kings Speech' or 'The Queen' but Streep's predictably flawless performance of Margaret Thatcher induces awe and rousing audience response.
The heavy handed, hypocritical propaganda hits too many false notes to care two 'truffulas' about.
A smart, engaging, adult comedy that is as comfortable being acerbically honest as it is being, ultimately, rather old-fashioned.
This low budget, Utah produced fantasy gamer comedy should be a colossal failure but good writing, an able cast, and a Napolean Dynamite spirit make for surprising, if odd, fun.
For those who aren't opposed to a little 'Why?' in their sci-fi, Ridley offers a penetrating other-worldly adventure like few films in recent memory.
It may not be the hero story that parents expect, or that the title implies...unexpectedly heavy stuff for a 'kids' movie. But if not Pixar then who?
Formulaic, unoriginal suspense thriller aided by a plot twist and good leads, that might delight the less-gore-is-more teenage audience.
movie_title: House at the End of the Street (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Maybe it's the timing of the release, coming at the dead zone of post-summer and pre-fall cinematic fare..but 'The Words' has enough going for it to be recommended.
Delivers a serviceable piece of updated movie product.
Maybe the plot's a little thin, but this is end of summer escapism at its best and it guarantees you'll never look at a biker in NYC the same way again.
Instead of mindless action, a more personal WWII story and though a little corny at times, it has a nice twist and a gripping, heartfelt ending that bring it home.
Absolutely not the comedy it implies, this mostly serious, very frank story is simplistic, even awkward, but captivates because of the leads.
If a group of your witty, talented and absolutely committed friends made a movie, this is the kind of truly 'indie' film to which they would aspire.
Nicely overlaps the previous films while carving a name of its own
An illustrative dividing line: REO Speedwagon is probably thrilled to death to be on this soundtrack - meanwhile Joan Jett is likely embarrassed that she is too.
Overcomes its overdone 'rising star' formula with surprising drama, decent songs,breakout performances and a haunting swan song of Whitney Houston.
This propaganda style doc is too busy evoking intolerance (ironically) and fear mongering to provoke any rational analysis of the facts.
Examines the costs of broken, fatherless relationships in subtle but direct ways. Yet it is not a downer of a movie, nor is it superficially cheery. A great cast helps.
Quirky, random, and surprisingly endearing for a Wes Anderson film--likely his best.
A decent movie by any measurement, it can't avoid being compared to the previous films, by that standard it isn't a game changer but Webb shows considerable promise.
Quietly and consistently charming a real hoot with a terrificly nuanced performance by Jack Black.
Kids will love this film and parents won't be bored for a minute.
Complex and comprehensive, beautiful if bloated, is nonetheless superlative filmmaking and even though over 160 minutes manages to rivet the senses in every frame.
Has the look and spirit of the time down pat. Unfortunately it captures only the worst of the typical misogynistic, foul mouthed druggie losers of the period.
Can't be construed as a hatchet job, nor does the polite and well-spoken D'Souza seem to aspire to such...yet it doesn't succeed as sheer bravura entertainment.
Seyfried does yeoman's work here -- but she has been in her share of clunkers and deserves better material.
If 'The Hunger Games' represents the latest book-turned-film blockbuster franchise built on the backs of fanatical adolescents then this is progress indeed.
Like motion picture Yoga--quietly cathartic and just the thing to raise your kids on.
Not an improvement on John Carpenter's groundbreaking 1982 original, but sufficiently horrific, tense and well-paced, and aided by minor changes and current technology.
It's as if the filmmakers decided, 'We're sticking with the basic script, but this ain't your mama's 'Footloose.'
Silly, corny and featuring nearly every boxing cliché... But fighting robots? Dads and their young sons will have a blast.
What it lacks in sheer insight it makes up for in bravura.
Neither particularly romantic nor comedic, nonetheless represents a middling love story that should suit most of its intended audience relying on the chemistry of its stars.
Misdirection might be a good word to describe this psychological thriller whose twist will either delight or annoy audiences. Give it credit for the surprise.
Deftly illustrates how life is complicated and it is that rare family film that portrays life's real challenges without glossing over the complexities of relationships.
A fascinating and entertaining peek inside the part of big-time sports that we rarely see and an odd couple's determination to think outside the batter's box.
Anderson has crafted a beautiful and rambunctious film that is in many ways a lot more fun than the last few Disney "Pirates of the Caribbean" films.
While not an elite action film, and overall disappointing, its stars compliment a witty script, a couple of cool fight scenes, and exotic locales.
Star-studded and well-directed pandemic story that offers style at the expense of thrills, any emotional connection, and at times, logic.
An intriguing premise that never quite reaches liftoff.
Some will scoff that it covers familiar territory or that the message should have been angrier and louder...but there is beauty in its lack of heavy handed sermonizing.
Preposterous at times, but smart and heartfelt too.
The film doesn't try to take on the quasi-political undertones of the 1968 original, but it makes its own case as a personalized science fiction drama.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Impressionistic may be a nice way to describe this often baffling mix of stunning cosmic imagery mixed with random snapshots of familial struggle...very, very different..
Combines the right elements of brisk storytelling and light touches of comedy without resorting to gimmicks or bombast.
More science-fiction-y than most superhero films with some cool intergalactic visuals, the story can't quite make the most of Ryan Reynolds' charisma...
That rare film that can shock both with its uncommonly cool style and chillingly raw substance.
An interesting, literal 'living on borrowed time' premise doesn't quite live up to its ambition but cool film work and Justin Timberlake keep things interesting.
Dares to preach its highly controversial message in order to inspire the faithful while risking the ire of critics and non-believers. Its message? Fathers, man up.
By honestly telling her story country western star Chely Wright has made a powerful, unforgettable coming out story stripped of melodrama yet unexpectedly heartbreaking.
The fast-paced jokes help overcome the preposterous covert underpinnings.
Campy humor and excellent visual effects help star and ever perplexing Nicholas Cage, who once won an Oscar.
The 3D treatment is fine, but not necessary to enjoy this most cuddly of kitty concoctions.
A gripping, survivalist drama with more humanity than expected.
There's some pretty tricky material for Payne and crew to navigate, but anchored by a terrific cast it's a journey of hurt and healing that lingers.
It may try too hard, and it borders on the implausible early and often, but the performance of newcomer Thomas Horn is relentlessly earnest and believable.
If there has been a musical-based movie that contains a sweeter collection of song numbers to go with a more inane script one doesn't come to mind.
Sure it's derivative, but it's also colorful, twisty, and fast-paced enough in execution.
Thanks to Crowe's steady hand and a talented, likeable cast, it is an appealing and family-friendly confection.
Whether you see the 'The Artist' for its nostalgia or its novelty, its joyous spirit is undeniable.
Cruises on the WOW! factor.
Along with the wondrous visuals, a rollicking adventure that careens at a breakneck speed from one death and gravity defying adventure to the next.
Fans of the first film will find plenty to still enjoy especially the lightening pace, banter and camaraderie of Downey Jr. and Law...despite an over-reliance on slow-mo.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Spielberg has fashioned a timeless classic out of a horse's journey that powerfully and memorably becomes our journey as well.
The cinematic equivalent of a piece of New York style cheesecake and about as artistically satisfying.
Who knew? The director who put the rage in Raging Bull the fear in Cape Fear and the mean in Mean Streets could make a family-friendly, dazzling 3D film.
Quietly spellbinding until the film's astonishing final 20 minutes which make it one of the year's best.
Occupy this: A feisty and funny heist movie with a nice turn by some guy named Eddie Murphy.
Ultimately a film that offers compelling details of a powerful but peculiar figure but the full picture remains just as enigmatic as Hoover himself.
If you are a novice this kind of material is suitably spooky. To the veteran, less so.
Outside of Haley's turn as Rorschach, the cast generally flounders on a raft of exposition-heavy words bobbing in an uncaring sea of ambitious visuals.
A rather lazily imagined, though energetically executed pastiche of big screen sci-fi clichés seemingly appropriated at random from other films.
Eastwood's latest confirms its director as the dean of American melodramatists and as an accomplished yet unadventurous artist as uncomfortable with ambiguity as his admirers appear to be.
Emotionally satisfying in a way that most other MCU movies can only dream of being.
Ultimately, Rogue One is a movie for Star Wars fans.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie based on a fictional encyclopedia, Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them is anything but tedious.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This Is Spinal Tap,"the funniest rock 'n' roll movie ever made...
It's a small-scale film, but it packs a solid punch.
The Onion may continue to thrive as a satirical, fake news Web site, newspaper and publisher of books, but The Onion Movie, a straight-to-DVD release, is a tired sketch-comedy collection.

In addition to being a taut and exciting war film, with realistic combat scenes and flashbacks and flash-forwards to the soldiers' civilian lives, Only the Brave serves to educate viewers about the diversity of the Japanese American troops.
The darkly realistic cinematography of Michael Simmonds gives the film a near-documentary style in its depiction of the endless, physically draining work.
A small film about a high school teacher in an elite Manhattan prep school, but it's filled with large doses of wit and insight.
The new 3:10 to Yuma will have to be quite a film to stand up to the original.
Its makers and star have produced a hackneyed piece of patriotic gore.
